play.title: The Second Part of Henry the Fourth

persona.persdescription: King Henry IV is the same as the Bullingbrook of Richard II and the King of Henry IV, Part One. Much older and wearier now, he suffers dreadfully from insomnia and lingering guilt over his usurpation of the throne. Rebellions against him continually keep him from going on crusade to Jerusalem as he hopes to do in expiation of his guilt. He is subject to fits where his vision blurs before he falls unconscious, and slips into coma-like sleeps where it is impossible to tell if he is still alive. If continual treasons against him and physical illness were not enough, his cares are increased by the fact that his eldest son and heir, Prince Harry, is a wastrel who spends most of his time in bars and has even been thrown in jail for being publicly disorderly. The King is too ill to lead his armies against the new rebellion himself, and has to entrust his forces to his second son, John of Lancaster rather than to his heir. Henry has lost all hope for Prince Harry, and is driven to the point of begging his three other sons to restrain their brother once the latter takes the throne. The combination of paternal disappointment and worry for his kingdom drives him to a passionate outburst even on his deathbed. He is reconciled with Harry just prior to his death. Known as a crafty politician, Henry is still enough of one as he lies dying that he can recommend that Harry avoid rebellions against himself by spending all of the nobles’ energies in fighting wars elsewhere. Haunted by a prophecy that he should die in Jerusalem, he fulfills it by insisting on being carried to a chamber of that name within his palace. Henry is as much as he can be a just king, glad to have servants who respect the law, and approving of the Lord Chief Justice for not treating Prince Harry any differently from other troublemakers.

Prince Harry, sometimes known as Monmouth, is the same as the Prince of Henry IV, Part One. Despite his apparent reformation in that play, he has since the battle of Shrewsbury gone back to his disreputable ways, playing pranks on Falstaff, mocking Poins, consorting with prostitutes and tavern-keepers. He has even been sent to prison after being publicly disorderly and slapping the Lord Chief Justice in court. He spends much less time with Falstaff, however, beginning to neglect him and preparing for his rejection once he takes the throne. Despite what King Henry and the whole world believes, he loves his father, but he is aware that saying so would have him tagged as a hypocrite because of his past conduct. He is extremely concerned about how he appears to the world, due to his master plan of setting himself up as a wastrel so that his reputation will be enhanced when he gives up that behavior on taking the throne. He is very quick to pick up the crown when he thinks that his father is dead; though he insists he did so to get used to the idea of kingship, his excuses are undercut by the fact that they are spoken in retrospect, and do not fully match what the audience saw on stage. As he is extremely successful at playing roles, the truth behind his feelings remains unknown. As King, he tests the loyalty of the Lord Chief Justice to make certain that fear of his new power will not undercut the old man’s honesty. His rejection of Falstaff and rounding up of his old companions has exactly the effect that he planned it to. Both as Prince and as King it is difficult to discern what his genuine emotions are; whether casting off his dissipation causes him any pain is up to the performer. Taking his father’s last words of advice, he plans a war in France to occupy his noblemen’s minds and energies and thus forestall rebellion. How this turns out can be discovered in Henry V.

Prince John of Lancaster is King Henry’s second son, and Prince Harry’s brother — the same as in Henry IV, Part One. A humorless man who drinks no alcohol and puts up poorly with Falstaff, he is a cold politician with a lawyer’s instinct for precise, hairsplitting words that enable him to trick the rebels into letting their soldiers go, thus avoiding a battle. He is quick to have rebels executed. He knows and respects the Lord Chief Justice, and shares his opinion of Prince Harry until the latter reassures them of his reformation. He has his ear to the ground and has a fair idea of what the new King’s next actions will be.

Humphrey, Duke of Gloucester is one of King Henry’s sons, and Prince Harry’s brother. As his father grows weaker, he grows worried about the public restlessness at the odd portents suggesting that the King is dying. He is as uncertain of Prince Harry’s worth as the others. He returns in Henry V.

Thomas, Duke of Clarence is one of King Henry’s sons, and Prince Harry’s brother. Of the King’s four sons, he is the closest to Harry, something that the King hopes will allow him to be a good influence once Harry takes the throne. He is worried about his father’s health. He returns in Henry V.

The Earl of Northumberland is the same as the Northumberland of Richard II and Henry IV, Part One. Having once helped Henry IV to usurp the throne, he is now theoretically rebelling against him. However, at the beginning of the play he is still pretending to be sick, which was his excuse for not joining his son Hotspur at the battle of Shrewsbury, leaving the latter under-strength; and he will later choose not to reinforce the Archbishop of York and the other rebels, with much the same results. The death of his son breaks his heart and leads him to rage against the King and help organize the second rebellion, but he is convinced by his wife and daughter-in-law to wait and see who will overcome rather than join in from the start. Waiting in Scotland, he raises an army with Lord Bardolph, but is beaten in battle by the Sheriff of Yorkshire. He is an old man, highly respected and powerful.

Scroop, Archbishop of York is the same as the character of the same name in Henry IV, Part One. Longing for revenge for the death of his brother Stephen (see Richard II), he grows convinces that the ills afflicting the country can be laid squarely at Henry IV’s door for his usurpation of the throne. He lends dignity to the rebellion by bringing the weight of his position behind it, and uses revenge for Richard II’s overthrow and murder as the official excuse for the uprising. He despises the common people, partly for their changeable opinions, and blames them for the state of affairs as it was Bullingbrook’s popularity with them that allowed him to easily take the throne. He is not as bright as he thinks he is, nor as good a judge of character; his certainty about what the King will do does not take into consideration the character of Prince John, whom he trusts far too readily, with the unfortunate result that he gets his head chopped off. He is an older man, whose beard is turning white.

Thomas, Lord Mowbray is the Earl Marshal of England, who joins the rebellion against the King. He is the son of the Mowbray of Richard II, who was supposed to fight a duel to the death with Bullingbrook, now King Henry IV. Not particularly intelligent, he is the most hot-headed of the rebels, partly for his father’s sake, though his understanding of that situation is less than perfect. He disapproves of the peace that the Archbishop negotiates with Prince John, as he would rather have fought it out; as it turns out, he is quite right to wish so, since the peace simply has him arrested and beheaded.

Lord Hastings is one of the rebels against King Henry IV. More optimistic than either the Archbishop or Lord Bardolph, he discounts the necessity of Northumberland’s support in making plans, trusting in the fact that the king’s own forces are divided into three armies in different parts of the country. Certain that the King is weak, he is foolish enough to think that a few threats will suffice, and he agrees to disperse the rebel army once Prince John has sworn to rectify the wrongs the rebels complain of. This overconfidence gets his head chopped off.

Lord Bardolph is one of the rebels against King Henry IV, who having heard that all was going well for their party rushes to the Earl of Northumberland’s to tell him that they’ve won. Not the best of news-gatherers, he forgets to double-check his sources, and is reluctant to admit that he was wrong. He proposes continuing the rebellion despite the scale of the defeat at Shrewsbury. He is much more cautious in planning the second campaign, insisting that it be properly thought out before it is begun. He is well-known enough to the Earl of Northumberland that the latter’s staff allow him access to the Earl’s house. He joins the latter in Scotland, where they raise an army but are defeated by the Sheriff of Yorkshire. Lord Bardolph is not to be confused with Falstaff’s companion of the same name.

Travers is one of Northumberland’s servants, whom he sent to find out news of the battle of Shrewsbury. Returning, he can bring no certain news, only report that Lord Bardolph suggested things were going well but that he passed another gentleman who claimed just the opposite.

Sir John Coleville is one of the rebels against King Henry IV. He surrenders to Falstaff after the rebels are tricked into defeat. He insists that in the place of his leaders he would have fought Prince John instead, and also that he only rebelled because of his superiors. This excuse does not do him any good, and he is carted off to be executed.

Warwick is one of King Henry’s noblemen, a loyal, reasonable and optimistic man. He seeks at all times to reassure his master and to help his comfort, whether it be in lowering the estimates of the rebels’ strength or hushing the princes to keep the King from hearing their discussion of his coming death. He is the only member of the court to suspect that Prince Harry’s dissipation might be a deception. Despite his reassurances to the King on the matter, however, he is concerned that Harry will prove the disappointment all the other courtiers fear. He returns in Henry V.

Westmorland is one of Henry IV’s lords, the same character as in Henry IV, Part One. Prince John sends him as an emissary to the rebels, with whom he argues at length over the justice of their cause. Mowbray’s misunderstanding of history leads him to scorn the young man. As the Prince’s second-in-command, he is an essential part of the plot to arrest the rebel leaders, convincing them that all is well, drinking with them, and offering a reasonable excuse for why the royal army has not dispersed. He has no philosophical difficulties with acting dishonorably towards traitors.
Surrey [mute role] is a nobleman highly trusted by Henry IV, one of the first he speaks to when he receives news of the new rebellion.

Sir John Blunt [mute role] is one of King Henry IV’s noblemen, among the first he calls when he hears of the new rebellion. He is sent with Prince John to deal with the Archbishop’s army, and is charged with taking Coleville and his men to be executed. He accompanies Prince John back to the palace.

Gower brings news to the Lord Chief Justice that the King and Prince Harry have returned from the wars in Wales and that part of the army has gone to reinforce Prince John’s forces against the rebels.
Harcourt is a messenger who comes from Scotland to announce to the King that Northumberland and Lord Bardolph have been defeated.

Lord Chief Justice is the highest judge of the land, equivalent to the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court. An old man with a strong sense of his responsibilities, he once imprisoned Prince Harry for public disorderliness after the latter hit him across the face in court. Upright and honest, he loathes Falstaff and all he stands for, and especially his influence on the heir to the throne. He worries about what will occur when the latter takes the throne, and fears that all the good done in Henry IV’s reign will be undone by Henry V. Refusing to flatter, he resists the temptation to speak well of Falstaff to the new King, and does not apologize for having sent him to prison. He is rewarded by keeping his place and being promised that he will be the new King’s chief advisor, and is later given charge of ensuring that Falstaff obey his banishment.

Poins is Prince Harry’s companion and accomplice, leading him on in his dissipated life. He is little more respectable than Falstaff and his crew, with whom he has an ongoing rivalry. Not overly rich, as he is a younger son, he has a rather small wardrobe. He is not afraid of speaking his true opinions before the Prince.

Sir John Falstaff is an excessively fat, excessively drunken, excessively cowardly, excessively witty, and excessively incorrigible rogue. Utterly shameless, he can talk his way out of almost any situation and rationalize any action, though he does not pull the wool over most courtiers’ eyes. Commoners are much more easily impressed by him. He is convinced that he still has Prince Harry’s love and that when the latter comes to the throne he will be the most influential man in the kingdom. Being rather poor, Falstaff tends to borrow inordinate amounts of money from people; he charms Hostess Quickly so much that even after she attempts to have him arrested for debt he can milk yet more money from her. He has often proposed marriage to her, keeping her in hope even as she arranges for him to enjoy Doll Tearsheet’s favors. He is very fond of Doll, the only person in whose presence he admits to feeling his age. He is not only fat and white-bearded: too much eating has given him gout, and too much time with whores has struck him with venereal disease, and he can no longer even tell which pains are caused by which disease. He has something of a feud with the Lord Chief Justice, who despises him and his influence on the Prince. He is easily bribed into letting draftees avoid the army, and can justify doing so. Calling on his old acquaintance Justice Shallow while mustering soldiers, he is able to cajole him into lending him a thousand pounds, for the sake of which he puts up with the old man’s nattering. Hearing of Prince Harry’s accession to the throne, he is so excited that he gallops full-tilt to London, willing to steal horses to do so, where he interrupts the new King’s coronation procession in the most shocking fashion. Rejected by the King, he attempts to convince his companions and himself that this is merely Harry putting on a show for the sake of respectability, but on being arrested by the Lord Chief Justice his argument falters. What happens to him afterwards is told in Henry V.

Bardolph is one of Falstaff’s followers, a man with a huge red nose and red marks all over his face. He is Falstaff’s assistant, collecting money from the drafted men who wish to bribe their way out of the army, fighting Pistol, delivering messages, and so forth. A rogue, he is arrested along with Falstaff at the end of the play. Not to be confused with the rebel Lord Bardolph, his further adventures are chronicled in Henry V.

Ancient Pistol is an officer in the army, an ensign-bearer. He is a swaggering braggart, trying to intimidate everyone he meets, speaking in overblown terms and stuffing his speech with foreign phrases and curses. It is said that he and Doll Tearsheet beat a man who later dies of his injuries. Pistol rushes to find Falstaff when Henry IV dies, hoping to rise in favor with the new King as Falstaff does. Unfortunately for him, this merely leads to his arrest. His further adventures are chronicled in Henry V.

Rumor, the Presenter speaks the Prologue of the play, reminding us of what occurred in Henry IV, Part One and setting the scene for the confusion of the first scene. Dressed in a costume covered in wagging tongues, Rumor is quite proud of itself and its effect on the world, and delighted at the opportunity to spread false news about the result of the battle of Shrewsbury.
The Porter guards the Earl of Northumberland’s gate. He knows Lord Bardolph well enough to let him go through to the orchard without further ado when the latter arrives.
Epilogue comes forward at the end to plead for mercy from the audience. He also offers to dance a jig for them.

Doll Tearsheet is a whore who is a particular favorite of Falstaff’s. She is drunken and has a remarkably foul mouth. She is fond of Falstaff, or at least makes a good show of it; she is also fond of raging at him. She is arrested and sentenced to be whipped for whoring at the end of the play, though she puts up a good fight (at least in words) against the beadles come to take her. She displeases Hostess Quickly by ending up pregnant, and is accused of having helped Pistol beat a man who later died of his injuries. She is quite good-looking, as common harlots go.

Hostess Quickly (often known as ‘Mistress Quickly’) is the owner of the Boar’s Head tavern in Eastcheap, and a bit of a madam on the side. She is the same as the Hostess of Henry IV, Part One. She does not have the best command of the English language, and often messes up her words. She is entirely under Falstaff’s spell, and has known him for 29 years: though he is indebted to her for a massive amount and continually puts of repaying her by promising to marry her instead, the moment he begins to speak to her he is able to convince her to lend him more, even though it may require her to pawn her richest possessions. She is also quick to offer Doll Tearsheet’s services to the fat knight. Despite her trade, the Hostess wishes to be seen as a respectable woman, and dislikes rowdy customers like Pistol. She is rather dithering, and sent all of a flutter whenever the Prince of Wales shows up in her inn. She is well-able to insult when need be, and is not pleased when Doll ends up pregnant, as it will hurt trade. She is arrested at the end of the play; her further adventures can be found in Henry V.

Lady Percy is the widow of Hotspur, the daughter-in-law of the Earl of Northumberland and his Lady. She grieves deeply for her husband, and convinces her father-in-law not to join immediately with the new rebellion but to wait and see how things turn out, not wishing to lose him as well as her husband. She has the courage to use his own desertion from the first rebellion against him. She is the same as the Lady Percy of Henry IV, Part One.

Lady Northumberland is the Earl of Northumberland’s wife. Grieving for the death of her son Hotspur, she helps her daughter-in-law persuade her husband to not join the rebellion, recommending Scotland as a good vantage-point from which to observe events.

Bullcalf is a countryman drafted to the King’s army. He is a muscular fellow who does not want to go to war. When faking a cough doesn’t succeed in getting him out of it, he resorts to bribery instead.

Feeble is a countryman drafted to the King’s army. A tailor for women, he is an honest man and a loyal subject, willing enough to go to battle, even when he sees that it is possible to bribe his way out of it.
Wart is a countryman drafted to the King’s army. He is extremely poor, and clearly starving.

Mouldy is a countryman drafted to the King’s army. He is not the brightest of fellows, but while he cannot catch one of Falstaff’s jokes, he is intelligent enough to know that bribery can get him out of going to war. He takes care of his mother.
Snare is one of two sergeants (with Fang) hired by Hostess Quickly to arrest Falstaff for debt. They are not exactly successful in this endeavor.
Davy is Justice Shallow’s servant. He is on familiar terms with his master, able to shift the subject of conversation and to make some attempts at wit to him. He dreams of seeing London some day.

Silence is a Justice of the Peace, whose daughter has Shallow as a godfather. As befits his name, he does not speak much, but he enjoys singing, especially once he has had a few drinks. Married to Shallow’s cousin, he pays for her brother’s stay at the university.

Shallow is a Justice of the Peace, an old, thin, decaying man verging on senility, at least 70 years old. He is close to Justice Silence, to whose daughter he is godfather. A great babbler, he is rarely quiet, and is forever remembering his days in university — or at least telling tales about his days in university. He has known Falstaff since that time, when he was a starving student. Now rich, he looks forward to the possibility of using Falstaff as a connection to court. He is nevertheless deeply involved in his country living, looking into the smallest details of the local life. He thinks himself much more wicked than he is, not realizing that in terms of drinking he is entirely out of his depth with Falstaff and his cronies. He is an honest and loyal servant of the King, not catching on to why Falstaff allows the two best men he drafts to go free. He lends Falstaff the enormous sum of a thousand pounds on expectation of getting it back when Prince Harry becomes King, so certain is Falstaff of the Prince’s favor. He follows the fat knight to Harry’s coronation, swept away by promises of lordship and who knows what else, and ends up arrested and sent to the Fleet prison.
Falstaff’s Page was given to him as a servant by Prince Harry. A good disciple to his master, he learns wit and insults from him, and serves him well. His further career can be found in Henry V.
Peto is one of Falstaff’s gang. He brings Prince Harry the news that some grave matter of state is afoot, and that soldiers are looking for Falstaff.

Morton was present at the battle of Shrewsbury, and hurries to Northumberland’s to tell him of the defeat and of Hotspur’s death. He is reluctant to admit him, but soon overcomes his fears and blames Northumberland to his face for the defeat. He persuades Northumberland to stick to the rebellion, and to help the Archbishop of York in his new uprising.
Fang is one of two sergeants (along with Snare) hired by Hostess Quickly to arrest Falstaff for debt. They are not exactly successful in this endeavor.
Sneak is the leader of a group of musicians who play at Hostess Quickly’s tavern, available for hire for private parties.
Shadow is a countryman drafted to the King’s army. He is a very slender man.

persona.persname: Servant to the Lord Chief Justice
persona.persdescription: Servant to the Lord Chief Justice does not appreciate Falstaff’s wit, and is incensed at the suggestion that he is not an honest man.

The Beadle is charged by the constables of the watch with having Doll Tearsheet publicly whipped for whoring. He has rather a hard time of arresting her and Hostess Quickly, as neither of them comes quietly. However, he has no qualms about having them bodily dragged away. He is a thin man.

Francis is one of the drawers (barmen) at Hostess Quickly’s tavern; he is the same character as the Francis in Henry IV, Part One. He knows Falstaff’s tastes well, and has no problems with helping Prince Harry to play a trick on the fat knight.

The Second Drawer is a barman at Hostess Quickly’s tavern. He sets the table for Falstaff’s dessert alone with Doll Tearsheet, and goes to find the musicians to accompany it. He remembers a number of the Prince’s jokes on Falstaff.
Will, the Third Drawer, is the third barman at Hostess Quickly’s tavern. He learns of the Prince and Poins’s plan to trick Falstaff and warns the other drawers not to let Falstaff know.
The Messenger comes to warn the rebel leaders of the approach of the royal army, and to offer a guess as to its size.

The First Strewer is one of the royal servants in charge of making sure the street for the new King’s procession is covered with rushes so that the nobility need not walk in the muck. He does not think they have put enough down.

The Second Strewer is one of the royal servants in charge of making sure the street for the new King’s procession is covered with rushes so that the nobility need not walk in the muck. Having heard the trumpets sound, he is worried that they are running out of time.

The Third Strewer is one of the royal servants in charge of making sure the street for the new King’s procession is covered with rushes so that the nobility need not walk in the muck. Though he hastens the job on, he thinks they have enough time to get the job done before the procession comes by.
The Officer is a captain in the rebel army. He is sent to discharge the soldiers and give them their pay when the loyal forces and the rebels come to an agreement.
King Henry’s Page [mute role] takes some letters to Surrey and Warwick, and summons them to the King’s side.

prologue.scenedescription: Rumor, painted full of tongues, says she has spread news of King’s defeat.
prologue.stagedir: Enter Rumor, painted full of tongues.

speech.speaker: RUM.
speech.line: Open your ears; for which of you will stop
The vent of hearing when loud Rumor speaks?
I, from the orient to the drooping west
(Making the wind my post-horse), still unfold
The acts commenced on this ball of earth.
Upon my tongues continual slanders ride,
The which in every language I pronounce,
Stuffing the ears of men with false reports.
I speak of peace, while covert enmity
Under the smile of safety wounds the world;
And who but Rumor, who but only I,
Make fearful musters and prepar’d defense,
Whiles the big year, swoll’n with some other grief,
Is thought with child by the stern tyrant war,
And no such matter? Rumor is a pipe
Blown by surmises, jealousies, conjectures,
And of so easy and so plain a stop
That the blunt monster with uncounted heads,
The still-discordant wav’ring multitude,
Can play upon it. But what need I thus
My well-known body to anatomize
Among my household? Why is Rumor here?
I run before King Harry’s victory,
Who in a bloody field by Shrewsbury
Hath beaten down young Hotspur and his troops,
Quenching the flame of bold rebellion
Even with the rebels’ blood. But what mean I
To speak so true at first? My office is
To noise abroad that Harry Monmouth fell
Under the wrath of noble Hotspur’s sword,
And that the King before the Douglas’ rage
Stoop’d his anointed head as low as death.
This have I rumor’d through the peasant towns
Between that royal field of Shrewsbury
And this worm-eaten hold of ragged stone,
Where Hotspur’s father, old Northumberland,
Lies crafty-sick. The posts come tiring on,
And not a man of them brings other news
Than they have learnt of me. From Rumor’s tongues
They bring smooth comforts false, worse than true wrongs.

scene.scenepersonae: (Lord Bardolph, Porter, Earl Northumberland, Travers, Morton)
scene.scenedescription: Lord Bardolph comes to Northumberland with news of victory, followed by Travers with news of defeat. Then Morton arrives and confirms the King’s victory over the insurrection, and the death of Northumberland’s son Hotspur. Northumberland swears revenge, especially since the King has sent an army to attack him. He learns that the Archbishop of York is also in arms, making the rebellion be on the side of true religion. Northumberland plans to combine with the Archbishop against the King.
scene.stagedir: Enter the Lord Bardolph at one door.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: Who keeps the gate here ho?
Where is the Earl?

speech.speaker: PORT.
speech.line: What shall I say you are?

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: Tell thou the Earl
That the Lord Bardolph doth attend him here.

speech.speaker: PORT.
speech.line: His lordship is walk’d forth into the orchard.
Please it your honor knock but at the gate,
And he himself will answer.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Earl Northumberland in a night-cap and supporting himself with a staff.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: Here comes the Earl.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: What news, Lord Bardolph? Every minute now
Should be the father of some stratagem.
The times are wild, contention, like a horse
Full of high feeding, madly hath broke loose,
And bears down all before him.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: Noble Earl,
I bring you certain news from Shrewsbury.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Good, and God will!

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: As good as heart can wish:
The King is almost wounded to the death,
And in the fortune of my lord your son,
Prince Harry slain outright, and both the Blunts
Kill’d by the hand of Douglas, young Prince John
And Westmorland and Stafford fled the field,
And Harry Monmouth’s brawn, the hulk Sir John,
Is prisoner to your son. O, such a day!
So fought, so followed, and so fairly won,
Came not till now to dignify the times,
Since Caesar’s fortunes.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: How is this deriv’d?
Saw you the field? Came you from Shrewsbury?

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: I spake with one, my lord, that came from thence,
A gentleman well bred and of good name,
That freely rend’red me these news for true.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Here comes my servant Travers, who I sent
On Tuesday last to listen after news.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: My lord, I overrode him on the way,
And he is furnish’d with no certainties
More than he haply may retail from me.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Now, Travers, what good tidings comes with you?

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: My lord, Sir John Umfrevile turn’d me back
With joyful tidings, and being better hors’d,
Outrode me. After him came spurring hard
A gentleman, almost forespent with speed,
That stopp’d by me to breathe his bloodied horse.
He ask’d the way to Chester, and of him
I did demand what news from Shrewsbury.
He told me that rebellion had bad luck,
And that young Harry Percy’s spur was cold.
With that he gave his able horse the head,
And bending forward strook his armed heels
Against the panting sides of his poor jade
Up to the rowel-head, and starting so
He seem’d in running to devour the way,
Staying no longer question.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Ha? Again.
Said he young Harry Percy’s spur was cold?
Of Hotspur, Coldspur? That rebellion
Had met ill luck?

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: My lord, I’ll tell you what:
If my young lord your son have not the day,
Upon mine honor, for a silken point
I’ll give my barony. Never talk of it.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Why should that gentleman that rode by Travers
Give then such instances of loss?

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: Who, he?
He was some hilding fellow that had stol’n
The horse he rode on, and, upon my life,
Spoke at a venter. Look, here comes more news.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Yea, this man’s brow, like to a title-leaf,
Foretells the nature of a tragic volume.
So looks the strond whereon the imperious flood
Hath left a witness’d usurpation.
Say, Morton, didst thou come from Shrewsbury?

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: I ran from Shrewsbury, my noble lord,
Where hateful death put on his ugliest mask
To fright our party.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: How doth my son and brother?
Thou tremblest, and the whiteness in thy cheek
Is apter than thy tongue to tell thy arrand.
Even such a man, so faint, so spiritless,
So dull, so dead in look, so woe-begone,
Drew Priam’s curtain in the dead of night,
And would have told him half his Troy was burnt;
But Priam found the fire ere he his tongue,
And I my Percy’s death ere thou report’st it.
This thou wouldst say, “Your son did thus and thus;
Your brother thus; so fought the noble Douglas”—
Stopping my greedy ear with their bold deeds,
But in the end, to stop my ear indeed,
Thou hast a sigh to blow away this praise,
Ending with “Brother, son, and all are dead.”

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: Douglas is living, and your brother yet,
But for my lord your son—

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Why, he is dead.
See what a ready tongue suspicion hath!
He that but fears the thing he would not know
Hath by instinct knowledge from others’ eyes
That what he fear’d is chanced. Yet speak, Morton,
Tell thou an earl his divination lies,
And I will take it as a sweet disgrace
And make thee rich for doing me such wrong.

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: You are too great to be by me gainsaid,
Your spirit is too true, your fears too certain.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Yet for all this, say not that Percy’s dead.
I see a strange confession in thine eye.
Thou shak’st thy head, and hold’st it fear or sin
To speak a truth. If he be slain, say so;
The tongue offends not that reports his death,
And he doth sin that doth belie the dead,
Not he which says the dead is not alive.
Yet the first bringer of unwelcome news
Hath but a losing office, and his tongue
Sounds ever after as a sullen bell,
Rememb’red tolling a departing friend.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: I cannot think, my lord, your son is dead.

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: I am sorry I should force you to believe
That which I would to God I had not seen,
But these mine eyes saw him in bloody state,
Rend’ring faint quittance, wearied and outbreath’d,
To Harry Monmouth, whose swift wrath beat down
The never-daunted Percy to the earth,
From whence with life he never more sprung up.
In few, his death, whose spirit lent a fire
Even to the dullest peasant in his camp,
Being bruited once, took fire and heat away
From the best-temper’d courage in his troops,
For from his metal was his party steeled,
Which once in him abated, all the rest
Turn’d on themselves, like dull and heavy lead.
And as the thing that’s heavy in itself
Upon enforcement flies with greatest speed,
So did our men, heavy in Hotspur’s loss,
Lend to this weight such lightness with their fear
That arrows fled not swifter toward their aim
Than did our soldiers, aiming at their safety,
Fly from the field. Then was that noble Worcester
So soon ta’en prisoner, and that furious Scot,
The bloody Douglas, whose well-laboring sword
Had three times slain th’ appearance of the King,
Gan vail his stomach and did grace the shame
Of those that turn’d their backs, and in his flight,
Stumbling in fear, was took. The sum of all
Is that the King hath won, and hath sent out
A speedy power to encounter you, my lord,
Under the conduct of young Lancaster
And Westmorland. This is the news at full.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: For this I shall have time enough to mourn;
In poison there is physic, and these news,
Having been well, that would have made me sick,
Being sick, have (in some measure) made me well.
And as the wretch whose fever-weak’ned joints,
Like strengthless hinges, buckle under life,
Impatient of his fit, breaks like a fire
Out of his keeper’s arms, even so my limbs,
Weak’ned with grief, being now enrag’d with grief,
Are thrice themselves. Hence therefore, thou nice crutch!
A scaly gauntlet now with joints of steel
Must glove this hand; and hence, thou sickly coif!
That art a guard too wanton for the head
Which princes, flesh’d with conquest, aim to hit.
Now bind my brows with iron, and approach
The ragged’st hour that time and spite dare bring
To frown upon th’ enrag’d Northumberland!
Let heaven kiss earth! Now let not Nature’s hand
Keep the wild flood confin’d! Let order die!
And let this world no longer be a stage
To feed contention in a ling’ring act;
But let one spirit of the first-born Cain
Reign in all bosoms, that each heart being set
On bloody courses, the rude scene may end,
And darkness be the burier of the dead!

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: This strained passion doth you wrong, my lord.

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: Sweet Earl, divorce not wisdom from your honor,
The lives of all your loving complices
Lean on your health, the which, if you give o’er
To stormy passion, must perforce decay.
You cast th’ event of war, my noble lord,
And summ’d the accompt of chance before you said,
“Let us make head.” It was your presurmise
That in the dole of blows your son might drop.
You knew he walk’d o’er perils, on an edge,
More likely to fall in than to get o’er;
You were advis’d his flesh was capable
Of wounds and scars; and that his forward spirit
Would lift him where most trade of danger rang’d;
Yet did you say, “Go forth!” and none of this
(Though strongly apprehended) could restrain
The stiff-borne action. What hath then befall’n?
Or what doth this bold enterprise bring forth
More than that being which was like to be?

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: We all that are engaged to this loss
Knew that we ventured on such dangerous seas
That if we wrought out life ’twas ten to one,
And yet we ventur’d for the gain propos’d,
Chok’d the respect of likely peril fear’d,
And since we are o’erset, venture again.
Come, we will all put forth, body and goods.

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: ’Tis more than time, and, my most noble lord,
I hear for certain and dare speak the truth,
The gentle Archbishop of York is up
With well-appointed pow’rs. He is a man
Who with a double surety binds his followers.
My lord your son had only but the corpse’,
But shadows and the shows of men, to fight;
For that same word, rebellion, did divide
The action of their bodies from their souls,
And they did fight with queasiness, constrain’d
As men drink potions, that their weapons only
Seem’d on our side; but for their spirits and souls,
This word, rebellion, it had froze them up,
As fish are in a pond. But now the Bishop
Turns insurrection to religion.
Suppos’d sincere and holy in his thoughts,
He’s follow’d both with body and with mind;
And doth enlarge his rising with the blood
Of fair King Richard, scrap’d from Pomfret stones;
Derives from heaven his quarrel and his cause;
Tells them he doth bestride a bleeding land,
Gasping for life under great Bullingbrook,
And more and less do flock to follow him.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: I knew of this before, but to speak truth,
This present grief had wip’d it from my mind.
Go in with me, and counsel every man
The aptest way for safety and revenge.
Get posts and letters, and make friends with speed—
Never so few, and never yet more need.

scene.scenepersonae: (Sir John Falstaff, Page, Lord Chief Justice, Servant)
scene.scenedescription: Falstaff, who has been pardoned his part in the robbery at Gadshill for his services at the battle of Shrewsbury, is wandering the streets in good humor when the Lord Chief Justice arrives. Falstaff attempts to avoid him, and then refuses to treat him seriously when the Chief Justice attempts to reprove him for his ill life. The Chief Justice absolutely refuses to give Falstaff a thousand pounds to help him raise troops for the expedition against Northumberland and the Archbishop. Almost out of money, Falstaff sends off letters to people who may lend to him.
scene.stagedir: Enter Sir John Falstaff alone, with his Page, following behind, bearing his sword and buckler.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Sirrah, you giant, what says the doctor to my water?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: He said, sir, the water itself was a good healthy water, but for the party that ow’d it, he might have more diseases than he knew for.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Men of all sorts take a pride to gird at me. The brain of this foolish-compounded clay, man, is not able to invent any thing that intends to laughter more than I invent or is invented on me: I am not only witty in myself, but the cause that wit is in other men. I do here walk before thee like a sow that hath overwhelm’d all her litter but one. If the Prince put thee into my service for any other reason than to set me off, why then I have no judgment. Thou whoreson mandrake, thou art fitter to be worn in my cap than to wait at my heels. I was never mann’d with an agot till now, but I will inset you neither in gold nor silver, but in vile apparel, and send you back again to your master for a jewel—the juvenal, the Prince your master, whose chin is not yet fledge. I will sooner have a beard grow in the palm of my hand than he shall get one of his cheek, and yet he will not stick to say his face is a face royal. God may finish it when he will, ’tis not a hair amiss yet. He may keep it still at a face royal, for a barber shall never earn sixpence out of it; and yet he’ll be crowing as if he had writ man ever since his father was a bachelor. He may keep his own grace, but he’s almost out of mine, I can assure him. What said Master Dommelton about the satin for my short cloak and my slops?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: He said, sir, you should procure him better assurance than Bardolph. He would not take his bond and yours, he lik’d not the security.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Let him be damn’d like the glutton! Pray God his tongue be hotter! A whoreson Achitophel! A rascally yea-forsooth knave, to bear a gentleman in hand, and then stand upon security! The whoreson smoothy-pates do now wear nothing but high shoes, and bunches of keys at their girdles, and if a man is through with them in honest taking up, then they must stand upon security. I had as live they would put ratsbane in my mouth as offer to stop it with security. I look’d ’a should have sent me two and twenty yards of satin (as I am a true knight), and he sends me security! Well, he may sleep in security, for he hath the horn of abundance, and the lightness of his wife shines through it; and yet cannot he see, though he have his own lanthorn to light him. Where’s Bardolph?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: He’s gone into Smithfield to buy your worship a horse.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I bought him in Paul’s, and he’ll buy me a horse in Smithfield; and I could get me but a wife in the stews, I were mann’d, hors’d, and wiv’d.

scene.stagedir: Enter Lord Chief Justice and Servant.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Sir, here comes the nobleman that committed the Prince for striking him about Bardolph.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Wait close, I will not see him.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: What’s he that goes there?

speech.speaker: SERV.
speech.line: Falstaff, and’t please your lordship.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: He that was in question for the robb’ry?

speech.speaker: SERV.
speech.line: He, my lord, but he hath since done good service at Shrewsbury, and (as I hear) is now going with some charge to the Lord John of Lancaster.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: What, to York? Call him back again.

speech.speaker: SERV.
speech.line: Sir John Falstaff!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Boy, tell him I am deaf.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: You must speak louder, my master is deaf.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: I am sure he is, to the hearing of any thing good. Go pluck him by the elbow, I must speak with him.

speech.speaker: SERV.
speech.line: Sir John!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What? A young knave, and begging? Is there not wars? Is there not employment? Doth not the King lack subjects? Do not the rebels need soldiers? Though it be a shame to be on any side but one, it is worse shame to beg than to be on the worst side, were it worse than the name of rebellion can tell how to make it.

speech.speaker: SERV.
speech.line: You mistake me, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Why, sir, did I say you were an honest man? Setting my knighthood and my soldiership aside, I had lied in my throat if I had said so.

speech.speaker: SERV.
speech.line: I pray you, sir, then set your knighthood and your soldiership aside, and give me leave to tell you you lie in your throat if you say I am any other than an honest man.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I give thee leave to tell me so? I lay aside that which grows to me? If thou get’st any leave of me, hang me; if thou tak’st leave, thou wert better be hang’d. You hunt counter, hence, avaunt!

speech.speaker: SERV.
speech.line: Sir, my lord would speak with you.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Sir John Falstaff, a word with you.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My good lord! God give your lordship good time of day. I am glad to see your lordship abroad. I heard say your lordship was sick, I hope your lordship goes abroad by advice. Your lordship, though not clean past your youth, have yet some smack of an ague in you, some relish of the saltness of time in you, and I most humbly beseech your lordship to have a reverend care of your health.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Sir John, I sent for you before your expedition to Shrewsbury.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: And’t please your lordship, I hear his Majesty is return’d with some discomfort from Wales.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: I talk not of his Majesty. You would not come when I sent for you.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: And I hear, moreover, his Highness is fall’n into this same whoreson apoplexy.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Well, God mend him! I pray you let me speak with you.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: This apoplexy, as I take it, is a kind of lethargy, and’t please your lordship, a kind of sleeping in the blood, a whoreson tingling.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: What tell you me of it? Be it as it is.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: It hath it original from much grief, from study, and perturbation of the brain. I have read the cause of his effects in Galen, it is a kind of deafness.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: I think you are fall’n into the disease, for you hear not what I say to you.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Very well, my lord, very well. Rather, and’t please you, it is the disease of not list’ning, the malady of not marking, that I am troubled withal.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: To punish you by the heels would amend the attention of your ears, and I care not if I do become your physician.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I am as poor as Job, my lord, but not so patient. Your lordship may minister the potion of imprisonment to me in respect of poverty, but how I should be your patient to follow your prescriptions, the wise may make some dram of a scruple, or indeed a scruple itself.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: I sent for you, when there were matters against you for your life, to come speak with me.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: As I was then advis’d by my learned counsel in the laws of this land-service, I did not come.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Well, the truth is, Sir John, you live in great infamy.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: He that buckles himself in my belt cannot live in less.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Your means are very slender, and your waste is great.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I would it were otherwise, I would my means were greater and my waist slenderer.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: You have misled the youthful prince.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: The young prince hath misled me. I am the fellow with the great belly, and he my dog.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Well, I am loath to gall a new-heal’d wound. Your day’s service at Shrewsbury hath a little gilded over your night’s exploit on Gadshill. You may thank th’ unquiet time for your quiet o’erposting that action.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My lord?

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: But since all is well, keep it so, wake not a sleeping wolf.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: To wake a wolf is as bad as smell a fox.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: What, you are as a candle, the better part burnt out.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: A wassail candle, my lord, all tallow; if I did say of wax, my growth would approve the truth.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: There is not a white hair in your face but should have his effect of gravity.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: His effect of gravy, gravy, gravy.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: You follow the young prince up and down, like his ill angel.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Not so, my lord. Your ill angel is light, but I hope he that looks upon me will take me without weighing, and yet in some respects I grant I cannot go. I cannot tell. Virtue is of so little regard in these costermongers’ times that true valor is turn’d berrord; pregnancy is made a tapster, and his quick wit wasted in giving reckonings; all the other gifts appertinent to man, as the malice of this age shapes them, are not worth a gooseberry. You that are old consider not the capacities of us that are young, you do measure the heat of our livers with the bitterness of your galls; and we that are in the vaward of our youth, I must confess, are wags too.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Do you set down your name in the scroll of youth, that are written down old with all the characters of age? Have you not a moist eye, a dry hand, a yellow cheek, a white beard, a decreasing leg, an increasing belly? Is not your voice broken, your wind short, your chin double, your wit single, and every part about you blasted with antiquity? And will you yet call yourself young? Fie, fie, fie, Sir John!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My lord, I was born about three of the clock in the afternoon, with a white head and something a round belly. For my voice, I have lost it with hallowing and singing of anthems. To approve my youth further, I will not. The truth is, I am only old in judgment and understanding; and he that will caper with me for a thousand marks, let him lend me the money, and have at him! For the box of the year that the Prince gave you, he gave it like a rude prince, and you took it like a sensible lord. I have check’d him for it, and the young lion repents,
marry, not in ashes and sackcloth, but in new silk and old sack.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Well, God send the Prince a better companion!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: God send the companion a better prince! I cannot rid my hands of him.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Well, the King hath sever’d you. I hear you are going with Lord John of Lancaster against the Archbishop and the Earl of Northumberland.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Yea, I thank your pretty sweet wit for it. But look you pray, all you that kiss my Lady Peace at home, that our armies join not in a hot day! For, by the Lord, I take but two shirts out with me, and I mean not to sweat extraordinarily. If it be a hot day, and I brandish any thing but a bottle, I would I might never spit white again. There is not a dangerous action can peep out his head but I am thrust upon it. Well, I cannot last ever, but it was alway yet the trick of our English nation, if they have a good thing, to make it too common. If ye will needs say I am an old man, you should give me rest. I would to God my name were not so terrible to the enemy as it is. I were better to be eaten to death with a rust than to be scour’d to nothing with perpetual motion.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Well, be honest, be honest, and God bless your expedition!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Will your lordship lend me a thousand pound to furnish me forth?

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Not a penny, not a penny, you are too impatient to bear crosses. Fare you well! Commend me to my cousin Westmorland.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: If I do, fillip me with a three-man beetle. A man can no more separate age and covetousness than ’a can part young limbs and lechery; but the gout galls the one, and the pox pinches the other, and so both the degrees prevent my curses. Boy!

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Sir?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What money is in my purse?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Seven groats and two pence.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I can get no remedy against this consumption of the purse; borrowing only lingers and lingers it out, but the disease is incurable. Go bear this letter to my Lord of Lancaster, this to the Prince, this to the Earl of Westmorland, and this to old Mistress Ursula, whom I have weekly sworn to marry since I perceiv’d the first white hair of my chin. About it, you know where to find me.

A pox of this gout! Or a gout of this pox! For the one or the other plays the rogue with my great toe. ’Tis no matter if I do halt, I have the wars for my color, and my pension shall seem the more reasonable. A good wit will make use of any thing. I will turn diseases to commodity.

scene.scenelocation: York. A room in the Archbishop’s palace.
scene.scenepersonae: (Archbishop of York, Thomas Mowbray Earl Marshal, Lord Hastings, Lord Bardolph)
scene.scenedescription: The insurgents make their plans and wonder whether they can be successful without Northumberland’s help; they remember all too well that after promising to help in Hotspur’s rebellion, Northumberland pulled out at the last moment and therefore doomed the effort. Hastings points out that the King has to fight on three fronts, including the Welsh and the French. The Archbishop suggests that they put their efforts into gaining popular support.
scene.stagedir: Enter the Archbishop of York, Thomas Mowbray Earl Marshal, the Lord Hastings, and Lord Bardolph.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Thus have you heard our cause and known our means,
And, my most noble friends, I pray you all
Speak plainly your opinions of our hopes.
And first, Lord Marshal, what say you to it?

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: I well allow the occasion of our arms,
But gladly would be better satisfied
How in our means we should advance ourselves
To look with forehead bold and big enough
Upon the power and puissance of the King.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: Our present musters grow upon the file
To five and twenty thousand men of choice,
And our supplies live largely in the hope
Of great Northumberland, whose bosom burns
With an incensed fire of injuries.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: The question then, Lord Hastings, standeth thus:
Whether our present five and twenty thousand
May hold up head without Northumberland?

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: With him, we may.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: Yea, marry, there’s the point!
But if without him we be thought too feeble,
My judgment is we should not step too far
Till we had his assistance by the hand.
For in a theme so bloody-fac’d as this,
Conjecture, expectation, and surmise
Of aids incertain should not be admitted.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: ’Tis very true, Lord Bardolph, for indeed
It was young Hotspur’s cause at Shrewsbury.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: It was, my lord, who lin’d himself with hope,
Eating the air, and promise of supply,
Flatt’ring himself in project of a power
Much smaller than the smallest of his thoughts,
And so with great imagination,
Proper to madmen, led his powers to death,
And winking, leapt into destruction.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: But by your leave, it never yet did hurt
To lay down likelihoods and forms of hope.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: Yes, if this present quality of war—
Indeed the instant action, a cause on foot—
Lives so in hope, as in an early spring
We see th’ appearing buds, which to prove fruit
Hope gives not so much warrant, as despair
That frosts will bite them. When we mean to build,
We first survey the plot, then draw the model,
And when we see the figure of the house,
Then must we rate the cost of the erection,
Which if we find outweighs ability,
What do we then but draw anew the model
In fewer offices, or at least desist
To build at all? Much more, in this great work
(Which is, almost, to pluck a kingdom down
And set another up), should we survey
The plot of situation and the model,
Consent upon a sure foundation,
Question surveyors, know our own estate,
How able such a work to undergo,
To weigh against his opposite; or else
We fortify in paper and in figures,
Using the names of men in stead of men,
Like one that draws the model of an house
Beyond his power to build it, who, half thorough,
Gives o’er, and leaves his part-created cost
A naked subject to the weeping clouds
And waste for churlish winter’s tyranny.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: Grant that our hopes (yet likely of fair birth)
Should be still-born, and that we now possess’d
The utmost man of expectation,
I think we are so a body strong enough,
Even as we are, to equal with the King.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: What, is the King but five and twenty thousand?

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: To us no more, nay, not so much, Lord Bardolph,
For his divisions, as the times do brawl,
Are in three heads: one power against the French,
And one against Glendower; perforce a third
Must take up us. So is the unfirm King
In three divided, and his coffers sound
With hollow poverty and emptiness.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: That he should draw his several strengths together,
And come against us in full puissance,
Need not to be dreaded.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: If he should do so,
To French and Welsh he leaves his back unarm’d,
They baying him at the heels. Never fear that.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: Who is it like should lead his forces hither?

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: The Duke of Lancaster and Westmorland;
Against the Welsh, himself and Harry Monmouth;
But who is substituted against the French,
I have no certain notice.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Let us on!
And publish the occasion of our arms.
The commonwealth is sick of their own choice,
Their over-greedy love hath surfeited.
An habitation giddy and unsure
Hath he that buildeth on the vulgar heart.
O thou fond many, with what loud applause
Didst thou beat heaven with blessing Bullingbrook
Before he was what thou wouldst have him be!
And being now trimm’d in thine own desires,
Thou, beastly feeder, art so full of him,
That thou provok’st thyself to cast him up.
So, so, thou common dog, didst thou disgorge
Thy glutton bosom of the royal Richard,
And now thou wouldst eat thy dead vomit up,
And howl’st to find it. What trust is in these times?
They that, when Richard liv’d, would have him die,
Are now become enamor’d on his grave.
Thou, that threw’st dust upon his goodly head
When through proud London he came sighing on
After th’ admired heels of Bullingbrook,
Cri’st now, “O earth, yield us that king again,
And take thou this!” O thoughts of men accurs’d!
Past and to come seems best; things present worst.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: Shall we go draw our numbers and set on?

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: We are time’s subjects, and time bids be gone.

scene.scenepersonae: (Hostess Quickly, Fang, Snare, Sir John Falstaff, Bardolph, Page, Lord Chief Justice, Men, Master Gower, Sergeant, Officers)
scene.scenedescription: Mistress Quickly sets Fang and Snare to arrest Falstaff for debt, but he, Bardolph and the page fight them off. The Lord Chief Justice and his men enter and stop the fray; the chief Justice refuses to believe a word Falstaff says in his own defense and orders him to settle the debt. As the Chief Justice is distracted by a message, Falstaff gives his word to pay up while actually borrowing more from Mistress Quickly. She invites him to dinner and offers to have Doll Tearsheet, his favorite whore, join him. The Lord Chief Justice tells Falstaff that he ought to have been long gone, and that he has orders to recruit more soldiers as he marches north.
scene.stagedir: Enter Hostess Quickly of the Tavern and an officer or two—Fang and Snare, Snare lagging behind.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Master Fang, have you ent’red the action?

speech.speaker: FANG.
speech.line: It is ent’red.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Where’s your yeoman? Is’t a lusty yeoman?
Will ’a stand to’t?

speech.speaker: FANG.
speech.line: Sirrah! Where’s Snare?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: O Lord, ay! Good Master Snare.

speech.speaker: SNARE.
speech.line: Here, here.

speech.speaker: FANG.
speech.line: Snare, we must arrest Sir John Falstaff.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Yea, good Master Snare, I have ent’red him and all.

speech.speaker: SNARE.
speech.line: It may chance cost some of us our lives, for he will stab.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Alas the day, take heed of him! He stabb’d me in mine own house, most beastly, in good faith. ’A cares not what mischief he does, if his weapon be out. He will foin like any devil, he will spare neither man, woman, nor child.

speech.speaker: FANG.
speech.line: If I can close with him, I care not for his thrust.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: No, nor I neither, I’ll be at your elbow.

speech.speaker: FANG.
speech.line: And I but fist him once, and ’a come but within my vice—

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: I am undone by his going, I warrant you, he’s an infinitive thing upon my score. Good Master Fang, hold him sure. Good Master Snare, let him not scape. ’a comes continuantly to Pie-corner (saving your manhoods) to buy a saddle, and he is indited to dinner to the Lubber’s Head in Lumbert street, to Master Smooth’s the silk-man. I pray you, since my exion is ent’red and my case so openly known to the world, let him be brought in to his answer. A hundred mark is a long one for a poor lone woman to bear, and I have borne, and borne, and borne, and have been fubb’d off, and fubb’d off, and fubb’d off, from this day to that day, that it is a shame to be thought on. There is no honesty in such dealing, unless a woman should be made an ass and a beast, to bear every knave’s wrong.
speech.stagedir: Enter Sir John Falstaff and Bardolph and the Boy Page.
speech.line: Yonder he comes, and that arrant malmsey-nose knave, Bardolph, with him. Do your offices, do your offices, Master Fang and Master Snare, do me, do me, do me your offices.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: How now, whose mare’s dead? What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: FANG.
speech.line: I arrest you at the suit of Mistress Quickly.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Away, varlets! Draw, Bardolph, cut me off the villain’s head, throw the quean in the channel.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Throw me in the channel? I’ll throw thee in the channel. Wilt thou? Wilt thou? Thou bastardly rogue! Murder, murder! Ah, thou honeysuckle villain! Wilt thou kill God’s officers and the King’s? Ah, thou honeyseed rogue! Thou art a honeyseed, a man-queller, and a woman-queller.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Keep them off, Bardolph.

speech.speaker: OFFICER.
speech.line: A rescue! A rescue!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Good people, bring a rescue or two.
Thou wo’t, wo’t thou? Thou wo’t, wo’t ta? Do, do, thou rogue! Do, thou hempseed!

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Away, you scullion! You rampallian! You fustilarian! I’ll tickle your catastrophe.

scene.stagedir: Enter Lord Chief Justice and his Men.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: What is the matter? Keep the peace here, ho!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Good my lord, be good to me; I beseech you stand to me.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: How now, Sir John? What are you brawling here?
Doth this become your place, your time, and business?
You should have been well on your way to York.
Stand from him, fellow, wherefore hang’st thou upon him?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: O my most worshipful lord, and’t please your Grace, I am a poor widow of Eastcheap, and he is arrested at my suit.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: For what sum?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: It is more than for some, my lord, it is for all I have. He hath eaten me out of house and home, he hath put all my substance into that fat belly of his, but I will have some of it out again, or I will ride thee a’ nights like the mare.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I think I am as like to ride the mare, if I have any vantage of ground to get up.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: How comes this, Sir John? What man of good temper would endure this tempest of exclamation? Are you not asham’d to enforce a poor widow to so rough a course to come by her own?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What is the gross sum that I owe thee?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Marry, if thou wert an honest man, thyself and the money too. Thou didst swear to me upon a parcel-gilt goblet, sitting in my Dauphin chamber, at the round table by a sea-coal fire, upon Wednesday in Wheeson week, when the Prince broke thy head for liking his father to a singing-man of Windsor, thou didst swear to me then, as I was washing thy wound, to marry me and make me my lady thy wife. Canst thou deny it? Did not goodwife Keech, the butcher’s wife, come in then and call me gossip Quickly? Coming in to borrow a mess of vinegar, telling us she had a good dish of prawns, whereby thou didst desire to eat some, whereby I told thee they were ill for a green wound? And didst thou not, when she was gone down stairs, desire me to be no more so familiarity with such poor people, saying that ere long they should call me madam? And didst thou not kiss me, and bid me fetch thee thirty shillings? I put thee now to thy book-oath. Deny it if thou canst.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My lord, this is a poor mad soul, and she says up and down the town that her eldest son is like you. She hath been in good case, and the truth is, poverty hath distracted her. But for these foolish officers, I beseech you I may have redress against them.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Sir John, Sir John, I am well acquainted with your manner of wrenching the true cause the false way. It is not a confident brow, nor the throng of words that come with such more than impudent sauciness from you, can thrust me from a level consideration. You have, as it appears to me, practic’d upon the easy-yielding spirit of this woman, and made her serve your uses both in purse and in person.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Yea, in truth, my lord.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Pray thee peace. Pay her the debt you owe her, and unpay the villainy you have done with her. The one you may do with sterling money, and the other with current repentance.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My lord, I will not undergo this sneap without reply. You call honorable boldness impudent sauciness; if a man will make curtsy and say nothing, he is virtuous. No, my lord, my humble duty rememb’red, I will not be your suitor. I say to you, I do desire deliverance from these officers, being upon hasty employment in the King’s affairs.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: You speak as having power to do wrong, but answer in th’ effect of your reputation, and satisfy the poor woman.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Come hither, hostess.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Now, Master Gower, what news?

speech.speaker: GOW.
speech.line: The King, my lord, and Harry Prince of Wales
Are near at hand. The rest the paper tells.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: As I am a gentleman!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Faith, you said so before.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: As I am a gentleman! Come, no more words of it.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: By this heav’nly ground I tread on, I must be fain to pawn both my plate and the tapestry of my dining-chambers.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Glasses, glasses, is the only drinking, and for thy walls, a pretty slight drollery, or the story of the Prodigal, or the German hunting in waterwork, is worth a thousand of these bed-hangers and these fly-bitten tapestries. Let it be ten pound, if thou canst. Come, and ’twere not for thy humors, there’s not a better wench in England. Go wash thy face, and draw the action. Come, thou must not be in this humor with me, dost not know me? Come, come, I know thou wast set on to this.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Pray thee, Sir John, let it be but twenty nobles. I’ faith, I am loath to pawn my plate, so God save me law!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Let it alone, I’ll make other shift. You’ll be a fool still.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Well, you shall have it, though I pawn my gown. I hope You’ll come to supper. You’ll pay me all together?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Will I live?
Go, with her, with her, hook on, hook on.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Will you have Doll Tearsheet meet you at supper?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: No more words, let’s have her.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt Hostess and Sergeant—Fang, Snare, and Bardolph.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: I have heard better news.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What’s the news, my lord?

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Where lay the King tonight?

speech.speaker: GOW.
speech.line: At Basingstoke, my lord.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I hope, my lord, all’s well. What is the news, my lord?

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Come all his forces back?

speech.speaker: GOW.
speech.line: No, fifteen hundred foot, five hundred horse,
Are march’d up to my Lord of Lancaster,
Against Northumberland and the Archbishop.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Comes the King back from Wales, my noble lord?

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: You shall have letters of me presently. Come, go along with me, good Master Gower.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My lord!

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Master Gower, shall I entreat you with me to dinner?

speech.speaker: GOW.
speech.line: I must wait upon my good lord here, I thank you, good Sir John.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Sir John, you loiter here too long, being you are to take soldiers up in counties as you go.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Will you sup with me, Master Gower?

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: What foolish master taught you these manners, Sir John?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Master Gower, if they become me not, he was a fool that taught them me. This is the right fencing grace, my lord, tap for tap, and so part fair.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Now the Lord lighten thee! Thou art a great fool.

scene.scenedescription: Prince Hal mocks himself for his taste for the lower classes. Poins rebukes him for not being more serious when the King is as sick as he is, but Hal points out that if he wept, people would simply think him a hypocrite. Bardolph brings the Prince a letter from Falstaff, in which the knight insults Poins; in revenge, Poins and Hal decide to spy on Falstaff as he dines with Doll Tearsheet.
scene.stagedir: Enter the Prince Henry, Poins, with other.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Before God, I am exceeding weary.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Is’t come to that? I had thought weariness durst not have attach’d one of so high blood.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Faith, it does me, though it discolors the complexion of my greatness to acknowledge it. Doth it not show vildly in me to desire small beer?

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Why, a prince should not be so loosely studied as to remember so weak a composition.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Belike then my appetite was not princely got, for, by my troth, I do now remember the poor creature, small beer. But indeed these humble considerations make me out of love with my greatness. What a disgrace is it to me to remember thy name, or to know thy face tomorrow, or to take note how many pair of silk stockings thou hast, viz., these, and those that were thy peach-color’d once, or to bear the inventory of thy shirts, as one for superfluity, and another for use! But that the tennis-court-keeper knows better than I, for it is a low ebb of linen with thee when thou keepest not racket there; as thou hast not done a great while, because the rest of the low countries have made a shift to eat up thy holland. And God knows whether those that bawl out the ruins of thy linen shall inherit his kingdom: but the midwives say the children are not in the fault, whereupon the world increases, and kinreds are mightily strengthen’d.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: How ill it follows, after you have labor’d so hard, you should talk so idlely! Tell me how many good young princes would do so, their fathers being so sick as yours at this time is.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Shall I tell thee one thing, Poins?

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Yes, faith, and let it be an excellent good thing.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: It shall serve among wits of no higher breeding than thine.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Go to, I stand the push of your one thing that you will tell.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Marry, I tell thee it is not meet that I should be sad, now my father is sick, albeit I could tell to thee—as to one it pleases me, for fault of a better, to call my friend—I could be sad, and sad indeed too.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Very hardly, upon such a subject.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: By this hand, thou thinkest me as far in the devil’s book as thou and Falstaff, for obduracy and persistency. Let the end try the man. But I tell thee, my heart bleeds inwardly that my father is so sick, and keeping such vile company as thou art hath in reason taken from me all ostentation of sorrow.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: The reason?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: What wouldst thou think of me if I should weep?

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: I would think thee a most princely hypocrite.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: It would be every man’s thought, and thou art a blessed fellow to think as every man thinks. Never a man’s thought in the world keeps the road-way better than thine: every man would think me an hypocrite indeed. And what accites your most worshipful thought to think so?

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Why, because you have been so lewd and so much engraff’d to Falstaff.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: And to thee.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: By this light, I am well spoke on, I can hear it with mine own ears. The worst that they can say of me is that I am a second brother, and that I am a proper fellow of my hands, and those two things I confess I cannot help. By the mass, here comes Bardolph.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: And the boy that I gave Falstaff. ’A had him from me Christian, and look if the fat villain have not transform’d him ape.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: God save your Grace!

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: And yours, most noble Bardolph!

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Come, you virtuous ass, you bashful fool, must you be blushing? Wherefore blush you now? What a maidenly man-at-arms are you become! Is’t such a matter to get a pottle-pot’s maidenhead?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: ’A calls me e’en now, my lord, through a red lattice, and I could discern no part of his face from the window. At last I spied his eyes, and methought he had made two holes in the ale-wive’s petticoat and so peep’d through.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Has not the boy profited?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Away, you whoreson upright rabbit, away!

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Away, you rascally Althaea’s dream, away!

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Instruct us, boy, what dream, boy?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Marry, my lord, Althaea dreamt she was deliver’d of a fire-brand, and therefore I call him her dream.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: A crown’s worth of good interpretation. There ’tis, boy.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: O that this blossom could be kept from cankers! Well, there is sixpence to preserve thee.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: And you do not make him hang’d among you, the gallows shall have wrong.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: And how doth thy master, Bardolph?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Well, my lord. He heard of your Grace’s coming to town. There’s a letter for you.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Deliver’d with good respect. And how doth the martlemas, your master?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: In bodily health, sir.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Marry, the immortal part needs a physician, but that moves not him; though that be sick, it dies not.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: I do allow this wen to be as familiar with me as my dog, and he holds his place, for look you how he writes.

line.recite: “John Falstaff, knight”—Every man must know that, as oft as he has occasion to name himself; even like those that are kin to the King, for they never prick their finger but they say, “There’s some of the King’s blood spilt.” “How comes that?” says he, that takes upon him not to conceive. The answer is as ready as a borrower’s cap, “I am the King’s poor cousin, sir.”

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Nay, they will be kin to us, or they will fetch it from Japhet. But the letter:
“Sir John Falstaff, knight, to the son of the King nearest his father, Harry Prince of Wales, greeting.”

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Why, this is a certificate.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Peace!
“I will imitate the honorable Romans in brevity.”

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: He sure means brevity in breath, short-winded.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: “I commend me to thee, I commend thee, and I leave thee. Be not too familiar with Poins, for he misuses thy favors so much that he swears thou art to marry his sister Nell. Repent at idle times as thou mayst, and so farewell.
Thine, by yea and no, which is as much as to say, as thou usest him, Jack Falstaff with my familiars, John with my brothers and sisters, and Sir John with all Europe.”

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: My lord, I’ll steep this letter in sack and make him eat it.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: That’s to make him eat twenty of his words. But do you use me thus, Ned? Must I marry your sister?

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: God send the wench no worse fortune! But I never said so.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Well, thus we play the fools with the time, and the spirits of the wise sit in the clouds and mock us. Is your master here in London?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Yea, my lord.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Where sups he? Doth the old boar feed in the old frank?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: At the old place, my lord, in Eastcheap.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: What company?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Ephesians, my lord, of the old church.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Sup any women with him?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: None, my lord, but old Mistress Quickly and Mistress Doll Tearsheet.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: What pagan may that be?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: A proper gentlewoman, sir, and a kinswoman of my master’s.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Even such kin as the parish heckfers are to the town bull. Shall we steal upon them, Ned, at supper?

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: I am your shadow, my lord, I’ll follow you.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Sirrah, you boy, and Bardolph, no word to your master that I am yet come to town. There’s for your silence.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: I have no tongue, sir.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: And for mine, sir, I will govern it.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Fare you well; go.
This Doll Tearsheet should be some road.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: I warrant you, as common as the way between Saint Albons and London.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: How might we see Falstaff bestow himself tonight in his true colors, and not ourselves be seen?

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Put on two leathern jerkins and aprons, and wait upon him at his table as drawers.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: From a God to a bull? A heavy descension! It was Jove’s case. From a prince to a prentice? A low transformation! That shall be mine, for in every thing the purpose must weigh with the folly. Follow me, Ned.
