scene.scenedescription: Northumberland is on the verge of leaving to join the other rebels, but his wife and widowed daughter-in-law, Hotspur’s wife, persuade him to fly to Scotland and await the outcome instead.
scene.stagedir: Enter Northumberland, his wife, Lady Northumberland, and Lady Percy, the wife to Harry Percy.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: I pray thee, loving wife, and gentle daughter,
Give even way unto my rough affairs;
Put not you on the visage of the times,
And be like them to Percy troublesome.

speech.speaker: LADY N.
speech.line: I have given over, I will speak no more;
Do what you will, your wisdom be your guide.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Alas, sweet wife, my honor is at pawn,
And but my going, nothing can redeem it.

speech.speaker: LADY P.
speech.line: O yet for God’s sake, go not to these wars!
The time was, father, that you broke your word
When you were more endear’d to it than now,
When your own Percy, when my heart’s dear Harry,
Threw many a northward look to see his father
Bring up his powers; but he did long in vain.
Who then persuaded you to stay at home?
There were two honors lost, yours and your son’s:
For yours, the God of heaven brighten it!
For his, it stuck upon him as the sun
In the grey vault of heaven, and by his light
Did all the chevalry of England move
To do brave acts. He was indeed the glass
Wherein the noble youth did dress themselves:
He had no legs that practic’d not his gait;
And speaking thick (which nature made his blemish)
Became the accents of the valiant;
For those that could speak low and tardily
Would turn their own perfection to abuse
To seem like him; so that in speech, in gait,
In diet, in affections of delight,
In military rules, humors of blood,
He was the mark and glass, copy and book,
That fashion’d others. And him, O wondrous him!
O miracle of men! Him did you leave,
Second to none, unseconded by you,
To look upon the hideous god of war
In disadvantage, to abide a field
Where nothing but the sound of Hotspur’s name
Did seem defensible: so you left him.
Never, O never, do his ghost the wrong
To hold your honor more precise and nice
With others than with him! Let them alone.
The Marshal and the Archbishop are strong.
Had my sweet Harry had but half their numbers,
Today might I, hanging on Hotspur’s neck,
Have talk’d of Monmouth’s grave.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Beshrew your heart,
Fair daughter, you do draw my spirits from me
With new lamenting ancient oversights,
But I must go and meet with danger there,
Or it will seek me in another place,
And find me worse provided.

speech.speaker: LADY N.
speech.line: O, fly to Scotland,
Till that the nobles and the armed commons
Have of their puissance made a little taste.

speech.speaker: LADY P.
speech.line: If they get ground and vantage of the King,
Then join you with them, like a rib of steel,
To make strength stronger; but, for all our loves,
First let them try themselves. So did your son,
He was so suff’red; so came I a widow,
And never shall have length of life enough
To rain upon remembrance with mine eyes,
That it may grow and sprout as high as heaven,
For recordation to my noble husband.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Come, come, go in with me. ’Tis with my mind
As with the tide swell’d up unto his height,
That makes a still-stand, running neither way.
Fain would I go to meet the Archbishop,
But many thousand reasons hold me back.
I will resolve for Scotland; there am I,
Till time and vantage crave my company.

scene.scenelocation: London. The Boar’s Head Tavern in Eastcheap.
scene.scenepersonae: (Francis, Second Drawer, Will, Mistress Quickly, Doll Tearsheet, Sir John Falstaff, Ancient Pistol, Bardolph, Page, Prince Henry, Poins, Peto)
scene.scenedescription: The waiters at the inn prepare the room for Falstaff’s dessert, and agree to let the Prince and Poins take their places. Mistress Quickly brings in Doll Tearsheet, who has had too much to drink. Falstaff comes in, and he and Doll insult each other roundly, though the whore is saddened to see him leave for the wars. The braggart Pistol comes in, swaggering until Falstaff beats him out of doors. Poins and the Prince overhear as Falstaff badmouths both of them to Doll. She tries to cheer him up as he begins to feel his age. Hal and Poins reveal themselves and accuse him over what he has said, and he makes a valiant effort to talk himself out of trouble. Peto brings a command for the Prince to join his father, and Hal instantly sobers up; Falstaff, in the meantime, is sought out by a dozen captains, though after his farewells to the ladies he takes the time for a last tryst with Doll.
scene.stagedir: Enter a Drawer or two—Francis and a second Drawer.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: What the devil hast thou brought there? Apple-johns? Thou knowest Sir John cannot endure an apple-john.

speech.speaker: 2. DRAW.
speech.line: Mass, thou say’st true. The Prince once set a dish of apple-johns before him, and told him there were five more Sir Johns, and putting off his hat, said, “I will now take my leave of these six dry, round, old, wither’d knights.” It ang’red him to the heart, but he hath forgot that.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Why then cover and set them down, and see if thou canst find out Sneak’s noise. Mistress Tearsheet would fain hear some music.

speech.speaker: 3. DRAW.
speech.line: Dispatch. The room where they supp’d is too hot, they’ll come in straight.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Sirrah, here will be the Prince and Master Poins anon, and they will put on two of our jerkins and aprons, and Sir John must not know of it. Bardolph hath brought word.

speech.speaker: 3. DRAW.
speech.line: By the mass, here will be old utis, it will be an excellent stratagem.

speech.speaker: 2. DRAW.
speech.line: I’ll see if I can find out Sneak.

scene.stagedir: Enter Mistress Quickly the Hostess and Doll Tearsheet.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: I’ faith, sweet heart, methinks now you are in an excellent good temperality. Your pulsidge beats as extraordinarily as heart would desire, and your color, I warrant you, is as red as any rose, in good truth law! But, i’ faith, you have drunk too much canaries, and that’s a marvellous searching wine, and it perfumes the blood ere one can say, “What’s this?” How do you now?

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Better than I was. Hem!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Why, that’s well said; a good heart’s worth gold. Lo here comes Sir John.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: “When Arthur first in court”—Empty the jordan.—
“And was a worthy king.”
How now, Mistress Doll?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Sick of a calm, yea, good faith.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: So is all her sect; and they be once in a calm, they are sick.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: A pox damn you, you muddy rascal, is that all the comfort you give me?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: You make fat rascals, Mistress Doll.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: I make them? Gluttony and diseases make, I make them not.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: If the cook help to make the gluttony, you help to make the diseases, Doll. We catch of you, Doll, we catch of you. Grant that, my poor virtue, grant that.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Yea, joy, our chains and our jewels.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: “Your brooches, pearls, and ouches.” For to serve bravely is to come halting off, you know; to come off the breach with his pike bent bravely, and to surgery bravely; to venture upon the charg’d chambers bravely—

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Hang yourself, you muddy conger, hang yourself!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: By my troth, this is the old fashion, you two never meet but you fall to some discord. You are both, i’ good truth, as rheumatic as two dry toasts, you cannot one bear with another’s confirmities. What the good-year! One must bear, and that must be you, you are the weaker vessel, as they say, the emptier vessel.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Can a weak empty vessel bear such a huge full hogshead? There’s a whole merchant’s venture of Burdeaux stuff in him, you have not seen a hulk better stuff’d in the hold. Come, I’ll be friends with thee, Jack. Thou art going to the wars, and whether I shall ever see thee again or no, there is nobody cares.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Sir, Ancient Pistol’s below, and would speak with you.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Hang him, swaggering rascal! Let him not come hither. It is the foul-mouth’d’st rogue in England.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: If he swagger, let him not come here. No, by my faith, I must live among my neighbors; I’ll no swaggerers, I am in good name and fame with the very best. Shut the door, there comes no swaggerers here; I have not liv’d all this while to have swaggering now. Shut the door, I pray you.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Dost thou hear, hostess?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Pray ye pacify yourself, Sir John. There comes no swaggerers here.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Dost thou hear? It is mine ancient.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Tilly-fally, Sir John, ne’er tell me; and your ancient swagger, ’a comes not in my doors. I was before Master Tisick, the debuty, t’ other day, and, as he said to me—’twas no longer ago than Wed’sday last, i’ good faith— “Neighbor Quickly,” says he—Master Dumbe, our minister, was by then— “Neighbor Quickly,” says he, “receive those that are civil, for,” said he, “you are in an ill name.” Now ’a said so, I can tell whereupon. “For,” says he, “you are an honest woman, and well thought on, therefore take heed what guests you receive. Receive,” says he, “no swaggering companions.” There comes none here. You would bless you to hear what he said. No, I’ll no swagg’rers.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: He’s no swagg’rer, hostess, a tame cheater, i’ faith, you may stroke him as gently as a puppy greyhound. He’ll not swagger with a Barbary hen, if her feathers turn back in any show of resistance. Call him up, drawer.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Cheater, call you him? I will bar no honest man my house, nor no cheater, but I do not love swaggering, by my troth. I am the worse when one says swagger. Feel, masters, how I shake, look you, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: So you do, hostess.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Do I? Yea, in very truth, do I, and ’twere an aspen leaf. I cannot abide swagg’rers.

scene.stagedir: Enter Ancient Pistol and Bardolph and Boy Page.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: God save you, Sir John!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Welcome, Ancient Pistol. Here, Pistol, I charge you with a cup of sack, do you discharge upon mine hostess.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: I will discharge upon her, Sir John, with two bullets.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: She is pistol-proof, sir; you shall not hardly offend her.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Come, I’ll drink no proofs nor no bullets. I’ll drink no more than will do me good, for no man’s pleasure, I.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Then to you, Mistress Dorothy, I will charge you.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Charge me? I scorn you, scurvy companion. What, you poor, base, rascally, cheating, lack-linen mate! Away, you mouldy rogue, away! I am meat for your master.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: I know you, Mistress Dorothy.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Away, you cutpurse rascal! You filthy bung, away! By this wine, I’ll thrust my knife in your mouldy chaps, and you play the saucy cuttle with me. Away, you bottle-ale rascal! You basket-hilt stale juggler, you! Since when, I pray you, sir? God’s light, with two points on your shoulder? Much!

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: God let me not live, but I will murder your ruff for this.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: No more, Pistol, I would not have you go off here. Discharge yourself of our company, Pistol.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: No, good Captain Pistol, not here, sweet captain.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Captain? Thou abominable damn’d cheater, art thou not asham’d to be call’d captain? And captains were of my mind, they would truncheon you out for taking their names upon you before you have earn’d them. You a captain! You slave, for what? For tearing a poor whore’s ruff in a bawdy-house? He a captain! Hang him, rogue! He lives upon mouldy stew’d prunes and dried cakes. A captain! God’s light, these villains will make the word as odious as the word “occupy,” which was an excellent good word before it was ill sorted; therefore captains had need look to’t.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Pray thee go down, good ancient.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Hark thee hither, Mistress Doll.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Not I. I tell thee what, Corporal Bardolph, I could tear her. I’ll be reveng’d of her.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Pray thee go down.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: I’ll see her damn’d first, to Pluto’s damned lake, by this hand, to th’ infernal deep, with Erebus and tortures vile also. Hold hook and line, say I. Down, down, dogs! Down, faitors! Have we not Hiren here?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Good Captain Peesel, be quiet, ’tis very late, i’ faith. I beseek you now, aggravate your choler.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: These be good humors indeed! Shall pack-horses
And hollow pamper’d jades of Asia,
Which cannot go but thirty mile a day,
Compare with Caesars and with Cannibals
And Troiant Greeks? Nay, rather damn them with
King Cerberus, and let the welkin roar.
Shall we fall foul for toys?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: By my troth, captain, these are very bitter words.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Be gone, good ancient. This will grow to a brawl anon.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Die men like dogs! Give crowns like pins! Have we not Hiren here?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: A’ my word, captain, there’s none such here. What the good-year, do you think I would deny her? For God’s sake be quiet.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Then feed and be fat, my fair Calipolis.
Come give ’s some sack.
“Si fortune me tormente, sperato me contento.”
Fear we broadsides? No, let the fiend give fire.
Give me some sack, and, sweet heart, lie thou there.
Come we to full points here? And are etceteras no things?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Pistol, I would be quiet.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Sweet knight, I kiss thy neaf. What! We have seen the seven stars.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: For God’s sake thrust him down stairs. I cannot endure such a fustian rascal.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Thrust him down stairs! Know we not Galloway nags?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Quoit him down, Bardolph, like a shove-groat shilling. Nay, and ’a do nothing but speak nothing, ’a shall be nothing here.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Come, get you down stairs.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: What? Shall we have incision? Shall we imbrue?
Then death rock me asleep, abridge my doleful days!
Why then let grievous, ghastly, gaping wounds
Untwind the Sisters Three! Come, Atropos, I say!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Here’s goodly stuff toward!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Give me my rapier, boy.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: I pray thee, Jack, I pray thee do not draw.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Get you down stairs.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Here’s a goodly tumult! I’ll forswear keeping house afore I’ll be in these tirrits and frights. So! Murder, I warrant now. Alas, alas, put up your naked weapons, put up your naked weapons.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: I pray thee, Jack, be quiet, the rascal’s gone. Ah, you whoreson little valiant villain, you!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Are you not hurt i’ th’ groin? Methought ’a made a shrewd thrust at your belly.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Have you turn’d him out a’ doors?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Yea, sir. The rascal’s drunk; you have hurt him, sir, i’ th’ shoulder.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: A rascal! To brave me?

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Ah, you sweet little rogue, you! Alas, poor ape, how thou sweat’st! Come let me wipe thy face. Come on, you whoreson chops. Ah, rogue! I’ faith, I love thee. Thou art as valorous as Hector of Troy, worth five of Agamemnon, and ten times better than the Nine Worthies. Ah, villain!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Ah, rascally slave! I will toss the rogue in a blanket.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Do, and thou dar’st for thy heart. And thou dost, I’ll canvass thee between a pair of sheets.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: The music is come, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Let them play. Play, sirs. Sit on my knee, Doll. A rascal bragging slave! The rogue fled from me like quicksilver.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: I’ faith, and thou follow’dst him like a church. Thou whoreson little tidy Bartholomew boar-pig, when wilt thou leave fighting a’ days and foining a’ nights, and begin to patch up thine old body for heaven?

scene.stagedir: Enter, behind, Prince Henry and Poins, disguised.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Peace, good Doll, do not speak like a death’s-head, do not bid me remember mine end.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Sirrah, what humor’s the Prince of?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: A good shallow young fellow. ’A would have made a good pantler, ’a would ’a’ chipp’d bread well.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: They say Poins has a good wit.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: He a good wit? Hang him, baboon! His wit’s as thick as Tewksbury mustard, there’s no more conceit in him than is in a mallet.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Why does the Prince love him so then?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Because their legs are both of a bigness, and ’a plays at quoits well, and eats conger and fennel, and drinks off candles’ ends for flap-dragons, and rides the wild-mare with the boys, and jumps upon join’d-stools, and swears with a good grace, and wears his boots very smooth, like unto the sign of the Leg, and breeds no bate with telling of discreet stories; and such other gambol faculties ’a has, that show a weak mind and an able body, for the which the Prince admits him. For the Prince himself is such another, the weight of a hair will turn scales between their avoirdupois.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Would not this nave of a wheel have his ears cut off?

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Let’s beat him before his whore.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Look whe’er the wither’d elder hath not his pole claw’d like a parrot.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Is it not strange that desire should so many years outlive performance?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Kiss me, Doll.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Saturn and Venus this year in conjunction! What says th’ almanac to that?

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: And look whether the fiery Trigon, his man, be not lisping to his master’s old tables, his note-book, his counsel-keeper.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Thou dost give me flattering busses.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: By my troth, I kiss thee with a most constant heart.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I am old, I am old.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: I love thee better than I love e’er a scurvy young boy of them all.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What stuff wilt have a kirtle of? I shall receive money a’ Thursday, shalt have a cap tomorrow. A merry song! Come, it grows late, we’ll to bed. Thou’t forget me when I am gone.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: By my troth, thou’t set me a-weeping and thou say’st so. Prove that ever I dress myself handsome till thy return—well, hearken a’ th’ end.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Some sack, Francis.

speech.speaker: BOTH PRINCE. AND POINS.
speech.line: Anon, anon, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Ha? A bastard son of the King’s? And art not thou Poins his brother?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Why, thou globe of sinful continents, what a life dost thou lead?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: A better than thou: I am a gentleman, thou art a drawer.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Very true, sir, and I come to draw you out by the ears.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: O, the Lord preserve thy Grace! By my troth, welcome to London. Now, the Lord bless that sweet face of thine! O Jesu, are you come from Wales?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Thou whoreson mad compound of majesty, by this light flesh and corrupt blood, thou art welcome.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: How? You fat fool, I scorn you.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: My lord, he will drive you out of your revenge and turn all to a merriment, if you take not the heat.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: You whoreson candle-mine, you, how vildly did you speak of me even now before this honest, virtuous, civil gentlewoman!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: God’s blessing of your good heart! And so she is, by my troth.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Didst thou hear me?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Yea, and you knew me, as you did when you ran away by Gadshill. You knew I was at your back, and spoke it on purpose to try my patience.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: No, no, no, not so, I did not think thou wast within hearing.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: I shall drive you then to confess the willful abuse, and then I know how to handle you.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: No abuse, Hal, a’ mine honor, no abuse.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Not to dispraise me, and call me pantler and bread-chipper, and I know not what?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: No abuse, Hal.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: No abuse?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: No abuse, Ned, i’ th’ world, honest Ned, none. I disprais’d him before the wicked, that the wicked turns to the Prince might not fall in love with thee; in which doing, I have done the part of a careful friend and a true subject, and thy father is to give me thanks for it. No abuse, Hal; none, Ned, none; no, faith, boys, none.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: See now whether pure fear and entire cowardice doth not make thee wrong this virtuous gentlewoman to close with us. Is she of the wicked? Is thine hostess here of the wicked? Or is thy boy of the wicked? Or honest Bardolph, whose zeal burns in his nose, of the wicked?

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Answer, thou dead elm, answer.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: The fiend hath prick’d down Bardolph irrecoverable, and his face is Lucifer’s privy-kitchen, where he doth nothing but roast malt-worms. For the boy, there is a good angel about him, but the devil blinds him too.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: For the women?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: For one of them, she’s in hell already, and burns poor souls; for th’ other, I owe her money, and whether she be damn’d for that, I know not.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: No, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: No, I think thou art not, I think thou art quit for that. Marry, there is another indictment upon thee, for suffering flesh to be eaten in thy house, contrary to the law, for the which I think thou wilt howl.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: All vict’lers do so. What’s a joint of mutton or two in a whole Lent?

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: You, gentlewoman—

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: What says your Grace?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: His grace says that which his flesh rebels against.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Who knocks so loud at door? Look to th’ door there, Francis.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Peto, how now, what news?

speech.speaker: PETO.
speech.line: The King your father is at Westminster,
And there are twenty weak and wearied posts
Come from the north, and as I came along
I met and overtook a dozen captains,
Bare-headed, sweating, knocking at the taverns,
And asking every one for Sir John Falstaff.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: By heaven, Poins, I feel me much to blame
So idly to profane the precious time,
When tempest of commotion, like the south
Borne with black vapor, doth begin to melt
And drop upon our bare unarmed heads.
Give me my sword and cloak. Falstaff, good night.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt Prince and Poins, Peto and Bardolph.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Now comes in the sweetest morsel of the night, and we must hence and leave it unpick’d.Knocking within.More knocking at the door!
How now, what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: You must away to court, sir, presently,
A dozen captains stay at door for you.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Pay the musicians, sirrah. Farewell, hostess, farewell, Doll. You see, my good wenches, how men of merit are sought after. The undeserver may sleep when the man of action is call’d on. Farewell, good wenches, if I be not sent away post, I will see you again ere I go.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: I cannot speak. If my heart be not ready to burst—well, sweet Jack, have a care of thyself.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Farewell, farewell.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Well, fare thee well. I have known thee these twenty-nine years, come peascod-time, but an honester and truer-hearted man—well, fare thee well.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Mistress Tearsheet!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Bid Mistress Tearsheet come to my master.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: O, run, Doll, run, run, good Doll. Come.To Bardolph.She comes blubber’d.—Yea! Will you come, Doll?

scene.scenepersonae: (King, King Henry’s Page, Warwick, Surrey, Sir John Blunt)
scene.scenedescription: The King is suffering from insomnia, unable to shake his cares and the cares of kingship from himself. He recollects his usurpation of the throne, considering how men once friends can fall out over little things and end up dreadful enemies. Warwick assures the King that the rumor of 50,000 rebels is false, and promises the King that the situation is better than it looks, as Glendower has been killed. He begs the King to take some sleep, as his odd waking hours cannot help his illness. Henry agrees, still dreaming of his crusade to the Holy Land.
scene.stagedir: Enter the King in his night-gown, alone, followed by a Page.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Go call the Earls of Surrey and of Warwick;
But, ere they come, bid them o’er-read these letters
And well consider of them. Make good speed.
How many thousand of my poorest subjects
Are at this hour asleep! O sleep! O gentle sleep!
Nature’s soft nurse, how have I frighted thee,
That thou no more wilt weigh my eyelids down,
And steep my senses in forgetfulness?
Why rather, sleep, liest thou in smoky cribs,
Upon uneasy pallets stretching thee,
And hush’d with buzzing night-flies to thy slumber,
Than in the perfum’d chambers of the great,
Under the canopies of costly state,
And lull’d with sound of sweetest melody?
O thou dull god, why li’st thou with the vile
In loathsome beds, and leavest the kingly couch
A watch-case or a common ’larum-bell?
Wilt thou upon the high and giddy mast
Seal up the ship-boy’s eyes, and rock his brains
In cradle of the rude imperious surge,
And in the visitation of the winds,
Who take the ruffian billows by the top,
Curling their monstrous heads and hanging them
With deafing clamor in the slippery clouds,
That with the hurly death itself awakes?
Canst thou, O partial sleep, give then repose
To the wet sea-boy in an hour so rude,
And in the calmest and most stillest night,
With all appliances and means to boot,
Deny it to a king? Then (happy) low, lie down!
Uneasy lies the head that wears a crown.

scene.stagedir: Enter Warwick, Surrey, and Sir John Blunt.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Many good morrows to your Majesty!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Is it good morrow, lords?

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: ’Tis one a’ clock, and past.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Why then good morrow to you all, my lords.
Have you read o’er the letters that I sent you?

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: We have, my liege.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Then you perceive the body of our kingdom
How foul it is, what rank diseases grow,
And with what danger, near the heart of it.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: It is but as a body yet distempered,
Which to his former strength may be restored
With good advice and little medicine.
My Lord Northumberland will soon be cool’d.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: O God, that one might read the book of fate,
And see the revolution of the times
Make mountains level, and the continent,
Weary of solid firmness, melt itself
Into the sea, and other times to see
The beachy girdle of the ocean
Too wide for Neptune’s hips; how chance’s mocks
And changes fill the cup of alteration
With divers liquors! O, if this were seen,
The happiest youth, viewing his progress through,
What perils past, what crosses to ensue,
Would shut the book, and sit him down and die.
’Tis not ten years gone
Since Richard and Northumberland, great friends,
Did feast together, and in two year after
Were they at wars. It is but eight years since
This Percy was the man nearest my soul,
Who like a brother toil’d in my affairs,
And laid his love and life under my foot,
Yea, for my sake, even to the eyes of Richard
Gave him defiance. But which of you was by—
You, cousin Nevil, as I may remember—
When Richard, with his eye brimful of tears,
Then check’d and rated by Northumberland,
Did speak these words, now prov’d a prophecy?
“Northumberland, thou ladder by the which
My cousin Bullingbrook ascends my throne”
(Though then, God knows, I had no such intent,
But that necessity so bow’d the state
That I and greatness were compell’d to kiss),
“The time shall come,” thus did he follow it,
“The time will come, that foul sin, gathering head,
Shall break into corruption”: so went on,
Foretelling this same time’s condition
And the division of our amity.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: There is a history in all men’s lives,
Figuring the natures of the times deceas’d,
The which observ’d, a man may prophesy,
With a near aim, of the main chance of things
As yet not come to life, who in their seeds
And weak beginning lie intreasured.
Such things become the hatch and brood of time,
And by the necessary form of this
King Richard might create a perfect guess
That great Northumberland, then false to him,
Would of that seed grow to a greater falseness,
Which should not find a ground to root upon
Unless on you.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Are these things then necessities?
Then let us meet them like necessities;
And that same word even now cries out on us.
They say the Bishop and Northumberland
Are fifty thousand strong.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: It cannot be, my lord.
Rumor doth double, like the voice and echo,
The numbers of the feared. Please it your Grace
To go to bed. Upon my soul, my lord,
The powers that you already have sent forth
Shall bring this prize in very easily.
To comfort you the more, I have received
A certain instance that Glendower is dead.
Your Majesty hath been this fortnight ill,
And these unseasoned hours perforce must add
Unto your sickness.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I will take your counsel,
And were these inward wars once out of hand,
We would, dear lords, unto the Holy Land.

scene.scenepersonae: (Justice Shallow, Justice Silence, Mouldy, Shadow, Wart, Feeble, Bullcalf, Servants, Bardolph, Falstaff)
scene.scenedescription: Shallow gossips endlessly with Silence, impressing the other man with tales of his youth as a law student in London. Shallow is shocked as he realizes how many of his friends are now dead. He acts as though he were Falstaff’s bosom friend, having known him at law school, but soon proves to know little or nothing of Falstaff’s current life. The fat knight arrives to recruit soldiers with Justice Shallow’s help. He chooses the four most ragged soldier, as the two best choices bribe Bardolph to get them out of serving. Falstaff recalls that despite the Justice’s tales of his wild youth, the Shallow he remembers was a pathetic non-entity. He plans to take advantage of Shallow and Silence on his return.
scene.stagedir: Enter Justice Shallow and Justice Silence, meeting; Mouldy, Shadow, Wart, Feeble, Bullcalf, and Servants behind.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Come on, come on, come on, give me your hand, sir, give me your hand, sir. An early stirrer, by the rood! And how doth my good cousin Silence?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Good morrow, good cousin Shallow.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: And how doth my cousin, your bedfellow? And your fairest daughter and mine, my goddaughter Ellen?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Alas, a black woosel, cousin Shallow!

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: By yea and no, sir. I dare say my cousin William is become a good scholar. He is at Oxford still, is he not?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Indeed, sir, to my cost.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: ’A must then to the Inns a’ Court shortly. I was once of Clement’s Inn, where I think they will talk of mad Shallow yet.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: You were call’d lusty Shallow then, cousin.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: By the mass, I was call’d any thing, and I would have done any thing indeed too, and roundly too. There was I, and little John Doit of Staffords hire, and black George Barnes, and Francis Pickbone, and Will Squele, a Cotsole man. You had not four such swingebucklers in all the Inns a’ Court again; and I may say to you, we knew where the bona robas were and had the best of them all at commandement. Then was Jack Falstaff, now Sir John, a boy, and page to Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: This Sir John, cousin, that comes hither anon about soldiers?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: The same Sir John, the very same. I see him break Scoggin’s head at the court-gate, when ’a was a crack not thus high; and the very same day did I fight with one Samson Stockfish, a fruiterer, behind Gray’s Inn. Jesu, Jesu, the mad days that I have spent! And to see how many of my old acquaintance are dead!

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: We shall all follow, cousin.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Certain, ’tis certain, very sure, very sure. Death, as the Psalmist saith, is certain to all, all shall die. How a good yoke of bullocks at Stamford fair?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: By my troth, I was not there.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Death is certain. Is old Double of your town living yet?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Dead, sir.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Jesu, Jesu, dead! ’A drew a good bow, and dead! ’A shot a fine shoot. John a’ Gaunt lov’d him well, and betted much money on his head. Dead! ’A would have clapp’d i’ th’ clout at twelvescore, and carried you a forehand shaft a fourteen and fourteen and a half, that it would have done a man’s heart good to see. How a score of ewes now?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Thereafter as they be, a score of good ewes may be worth ten pounds.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: And is old Double dead?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Here come two of Sir John Falstaff’s men, as I think.

scene.stagedir: Enter Bardolph and one with him.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Good morrow, honest gentlemen.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: I beseech you, which is Justice Shallow?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: I am Robert Shallow, sir, a poor esquire of this county, and one of the King’s justices of the peace. What is your good pleasure with me?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: My captain, sir, commends him to you, my captain, Sir John Falstaff, a tall gentleman, by heaven, and a most gallant leader.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: He greets me well, sir. I knew him a good backsword man. How doth the good knight? May I ask how my lady his wife doth?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Sir, pardon, a soldier is better accommodated than with a wife.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: It is well said, in faith, sir, and it is well said indeed too. Better accommodated! It is good, yea indeed is it. Good phrases are surely, and ever were, very commendable. Accommodated! It comes of accommodo, very good, a good phrase.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Pardon, sir, I have heard the word. Phrase call you it? By this day, I know not the phrase, but I will maintain the word with my sword to be a soldier-like word, and a word of exceeding good command, by heaven. Accommodated: that is, when a man is, as they say, accommodated, or when a man is being whereby ’a may be thought to be accommodated—which is an excellent thing.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: It is very just. Look, here comes good Sir John. Give me your good hand, give me your worship’s good hand. By my troth, you like well and bear your years very well. Welcome, good Sir John.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I am glad to see you well, good Master Robert Shallow. Master Surecard, as I think?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: No, Sir John, it is my cousin Silence, in commission with me.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Good Master Silence, it well befits you should be of the peace.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Your good worship is welcome.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Fie, this is hot weather, gentlemen. Have you provided me here half a dozen sufficient men?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Marry, have we, sir. Will you sit?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Let me see them, I beseech you.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Where’s the roll? Where’s the roll? Where’s the roll? Let me see, let me see, let me see. So, so, so, so, so, so, so; yea, marry, sir. Rafe Mouldy! Let them appear as I call; let them do so, let them do so. Let me see, where is Mouldy?

speech.speaker: MOUL.
speech.line: Here, and’t please you.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: What think you, Sir John? A good-limb’d fellow, young, strong, and of good friends.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Is thy name Mouldy?

speech.speaker: MOUL.
speech.line: Yea, and’t please you.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: ’Tis the more time thou wert us’d.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha! Most excellent, i’ faith! Things that are mouldy lack use. Very singular good, in faith, well said, Sir John, very well said.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Prick him.

speech.speaker: MOUL.
speech.line: I was prick’d well enough before, and you could have let me alone. My old dame will be undone now for one to do her husbandry and her drudgery. You need not to have prick’d me, there are other men fitter to go out than I.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Go to, peace, Mouldy, you shall go. Mouldy, it is time you were spent.

speech.speaker: MOUL.
speech.line: Spent?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Peace, fellow, peace, stand aside, know you where you are? For th’ other, Sir John, let me see: Simon Shadow!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Yea, marry, let me have him to sit under, he’s like to be a cold soldier.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Where’s Shadow?

speech.speaker: SHAD.
speech.line: Here, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Shadow, whose son art thou?

speech.speaker: SHAD.
speech.line: My mother’s son, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Thy mother’s son! Like enough, and thy father’s shadow. So the son of the female is the shadow of the male. It is often so indeed, but much of the father’s substance!

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Do you like him, Sir John?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Shadow will serve for summer, prick him, aside for we have a number of shadows fill up the muster-book.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Thomas Wart!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Where’s he?

speech.speaker: WART.
speech.line: Here, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Is thy name Wart?

speech.speaker: WART.
speech.line: Yea, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Thou art a very ragged wart.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Shall I prick him, Sir John?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: It were superfluous, for ’s apparel is built upon his back, and the whole frame stands upon pins. Prick him no more.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha! You can do it, sir, you can do it, I commend you well. Francis Feeble!

speech.speaker: FEE.
speech.line: Here, sir.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: What trade art thou, Feeble?

speech.speaker: FEE.
speech.line: A woman’s tailor, sir.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Shall I prick him, sir?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: You may, but if he had been a man’s tailor, he’d ’a’ prick’d you. Wilt thou make as many holes in an enemy’s battle as thou hast done in a woman’s petticoat?

speech.speaker: FEE.
speech.line: I will do my good will, sir, you can have no more.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Well said, good woman’s tailor! Well said, courageous Feeble! Thou wilt be as valiant as the wrathful dove or most magnanimous mouse. Prick the woman’s tailor. Well, Master Shallow, deep, Master Shallow.

speech.speaker: FEE.
speech.line: I would Wart might have gone, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I would thou wert a man’s tailor, that thou mightst mend him and make him fit to go. I cannot put him to a private soldier that is the leader of so many thousands. Let that suffice, most forcible Feeble.

speech.speaker: FEE.
speech.line: It shall suffice, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I am bound to thee, reverend Feeble. Who is next?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Peter Bullcalf o’ th’ green!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Yea, marry, let’s see Bullcalf.

speech.speaker: BULL.
speech.line: Here, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: ’Fore God, a likely fellow! Come prick Bullcalf till he roar again.

speech.speaker: BULL.
speech.line: O Lord, good my lord captain—

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What, dost thou roar before thou art prick’d?

speech.speaker: BULL.
speech.line: O Lord, sir, I am a diseas’d man.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What disease hast thou?

speech.speaker: BULL.
speech.line: A whoreson cold, sir, a cough, sir, which I caught with ringing in the King’s affairs upon his coronation-day, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Come, thou shalt go to the wars in a gown. We will have away thy cold, and I will take such order that thy friends shall ring for thee. Is here all?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Here is two more call’d than your number, you must have but four here, sir. And so I pray you go in with me to dinner.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Come, I will go drink with you, but I cannot tarry dinner. I am glad to see you, by my troth, Master Shallow.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: O Sir John, do you remember since we lay all night in the Windmill in Saint George’s Field?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: No more of that, Master Shallow, no more of that.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Ha, ’twas a merry night. And is Jane Nightwork alive?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: She lives, Master Shallow.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: She never could away with me.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Never, never, she would always say she could not abide Master Shallow.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: By the mass, I could anger her to th’ heart. She was then a bona roba. Doth she hold her own well?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Old, old, Master Shallow.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Nay, she must be old, she cannot choose but be old, certain she’s old, and had Robin Nightwork by old Nightwork before I came to Clement’s Inn.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: That’s fifty-five year ago.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Ha, cousin Silence, that thou hadst seen that that this knight and I have seen! Ha, Sir John, said I well?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: We have heard the chimes at midnight, Master Shallow.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: That we have, that we have, that we have, in faith, Sir John, we have. Our watch-word was “Hem, boys!” Come let’s to dinner, come let’s to dinner. Jesus, the days that we have seen! Come, come.

speech.speaker: BULL.
speech.line: Good Master Corporate Bardolph, stand my friend, and here’s four Harry ten shillings in French crowns for you. In very truth, sir, I had as live be hang’d, sir, as go, and yet for mine own part, sir, I do not care, but rather, because I am unwilling, and for mine own part, have a desire to stay with my friends, else, sir, I did not care for mine own part so much.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Go to, stand aside.

speech.speaker: MOUL.
speech.line: And, good Master Corporal Captain, for my old dame’s sake stand my friend. She has nobody to do any thing about her when I am gone, and she is old, and cannot help herself. You shall have forty, sir.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Go to, stand aside.

speech.speaker: FEE.
speech.line: By my troth I care not; a man can die but once, we owe God a death. I’ll ne’er bear a base mind. And’t be my dest’ny, so; and’t be not, so. No man’s too good to serve ’s prince, and let it go which way it will, he that dies this year is quit for the next.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Well said, th’ art a good fellow.

speech.speaker: FEE.
speech.line: Faith, I’ll bear no base mind.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Come, sir, which men shall I have?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Four of which you please.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Sir, a word with you.
I have three pound to free Mouldy and Bullcalf.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Go to, well.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Come, Sir John, which four will you have?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Do you choose for me.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Marry, then, Mouldy, Bullcalf, Feeble, and Shadow.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Mouldy and Bullcalf! For you, Mouldy, stay at home till you are past service; and for your part, Bullcalf, grow till you come unto it. I will none of you.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Sir John, Sir John, do not yourself wrong. They are your likeliest men, and I would have you serv’d with the best.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Will you tell me, Master Shallow, how to choose a man? Care I for the limb, the thews, the stature, bulk, and big assemblance of a man? Give me the spirit, Master Shallow. Here’s Wart, you see what a ragged appearance it is. ’A shall charge you and discharge you with the motion of a pewterer’s hammer, come off and on swifter than he that gibbets on the brewer’s bucket. And this same half-fac’d fellow, Shadow, give me this man. He presents no mark to the enemy, the foeman may with as great aim level at the edge of a penknife. And for a retrait, how swiftly will this Feeble the woman’s tailor run off! O, give me the spare men, and spare me the great ones. Put me a caliver into Wart’s hand, Bardolph.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Hold, Wart, traverse! Thas, thas, thas.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Come manage me your caliver. So—very well, go to, very good, exceeding good. O, give me always a little, lean, old, chopp’d, bald shot. Well said, i’ faith, Wart, th’ art a good scab. Hold, there’s a tester for thee.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: He is not his craft’s master, he doth not do it right. I remember at Mile-end Green, when I lay at Clement’s Inn—I was then Sir Dagonet in Arthur’s show—there was a little quiver fellow, and ’a would manage you his piece thus, and ’a would about and about, and come you in and come you in. “Rah, tah, tah,” would ’a say, “bounce,” would ’a say, and away again would ’a go, and again would ’a come. I shall ne’er see such a fellow.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: These fellows woll do well, Master Shallow. God keep you, Master Silence, I will not use many words with you. Fare you well, gentlemen both, I thank you. I must a dozen mile tonight. Bardolph, give the soldiers coats.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Sir John, the Lord bless you! God prosper your affairs! God send us peace! At your return visit our house, let our old acquaintance be renew’d. Peradventure I will with ye to the court.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: ’Fore God, would you would.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Go to, I have spoke at a word. God keep you!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Fare you well, gentle gentlemen.
On, Bardolph, lead the men away.

As I return, I will fetch off these justices. I do see the bottom of Justice Shallow. Lord, Lord, how subject we old men are to this vice of lying! This same starv’d justice hath done nothing but prate to me of the wildness of his youth, and the feats he hath done about Turnbull Street, and every third word a lie, duer paid to the hearer than the Turk’s tribute. I do remember him at Clement’s Inn, like a man made after supper of a cheese-paring. When ’a was naked, he was for all the world like a fork’d redish, with a head fantastically carv’d upon it with a knife. ’A was so forlorn, that his dimensions to any thick sight were invisible. ’A was the very genius of famine, yet lecherous as a monkey, and the whores call’d him mandrake. ’A came ever in the rearward of the fashion, and sung those tunes to the overscutch’d huswives that he heard the carmen whistle, and sware they were his fancies or his good-nights. And now is this Vice’s dagger become a squire, and talks as familiarly of John a’ Gaunt as if he had been sworn brother to him, and I’ll be sworn ’a ne’er saw him but once in the Tilt-yard, and then he burst his head for crowding among the marshal’s men. I saw it, and told John a’ Gaunt he beat his own name, for you might have thrust him and all his apparel into an eel-skin. The case of a treble hoboy was a mansion for him, a court, and now has he land and beefs! Well, I’ll be acquainted with him if I return, and’t shall go hard but I’ll make him a philosopher’s two stones to me. If the young dace be a bait for the old pike, I see no reason in the law of nature but I may snap at him: let time shape, and there an end.

scene.scenelocation: Yorkshire. Within the Forest of Gaultree.
scene.scenepersonae: (Archbishop of York, Mowbray, Lord Bardolph, Hastings, Messenger, Westmorland, Prince John)
scene.scenedescription: The rebels have received news that Northumberland will not be joining them. Westmoreland comes to them from Prince John of Lancaster, the leader of the royalist forces, and asks them the reasons for their rebellion. The Archbishop lists off a number of grievances, but Westmoreland argues that they are all specious reasons for a revolt. The Archbishop sends him back to Prince John with a written list of the rebels’ complaints; in Westmoreland’s absence, the rebels confer and are divided over their chances of success. The Archbishop is convincing when he argues that the King is too weak to risk standing up to the rebellion. Westmoreland returns and asks the rebel leaders to come to a parley with Prince John, and they agree.
scene.stagedir: Enter the Archbishop of York, Mowbray, Lord Bardolph, Hastings, and others, within the forest of Gaultree.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: What is this forest call’d?

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: ’Tis Gaultree forest, and’t shall please your Grace.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Here stand, my lords, and send discoverers forth
To know the numbers of our enemies.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: We have sent forth already.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: ’Tis well done.
My friends and brethren in these great affairs,
I must acquaint you that I have receiv’d
New-dated letters from Northumberland,
Their cold intent, tenure, and substance thus:
Here doth he wish his person, with such powers
As might hold sortance with his quality,
The which he could not levy; whereupon
He is retir’d, to ripe his growing fortunes,
To Scotland, and concludes in hearty prayers
That your attempts may overlive the hazard
And fearful meeting of their opposite.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: Thus do the hopes we have in him touch ground
And dash themselves to pieces.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: Now, what news?

speech.speaker: MESS.
speech.line: West of this forest, scarcely off a mile,
In goodly form comes on the enemy,
And by the ground they hide, I judge their number
Upon or near the rate of thirty thousand.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: The just proportion that we gave them out.
Let us sway on and face them in the field.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: What well-appointed leader fronts us here?

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: I think it is my Lord of Westmorland.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: Health and fair greeting from our general,
The Prince, Lord John and Duke of Lancaster.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Say on, my Lord of Westmorland, in peace,
What doth concern your coming.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: Then, my lord,
Unto your Grace do I in chief address
The substance of my speech. If that rebellion
Came like itself, in base and abject routs,
Led on by bloody youth, guarded with rage,
And countenanc’d by boys and beggary—
I say, if damn’d commotion so appear’d
In his true, native, and most proper shape,
You, reverend father, and these noble lords
Had not been here to dress the ugly form
Of base and bloody insurrection
With your fair honors. You, Lord Archbishop,
Whose see is by a civil peace maintain’d,
Whose beard the silver hand of peace hath touch’d,
Whose learning and good letters peace hath tutor’d,
Whose white investments figure innocence,
The dove, and very blessed spirit of peace,
Wherefore do you so ill translate yourself
Out of the speech of peace that bears such grace,
Into the harsh and boist’rous tongue of war?
Turning your books to graves, your ink to blood,
Your pens to lances, and your tongue divine
To a loud trumpet and a point of war?

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Wherefore do I this? So the question stands.
Briefly, to this end: we are all diseas’d,
And with our surfeiting and wanton hours
Have brought ourselves into a burning fever,
And we must bleed for it; of which disease
Our late King Richard (being infected) died.
But, my most noble Lord of Westmorland,
I take not on me here as a physician,
Nor do I as an enemy to peace
Troop in the throngs of military men;
But rather show a while like fearful war
To diet rank minds sick of happiness,
And purge th’ obstructions which begin to stop
Our very veins of life. Hear me more plainly.
I have in equal balance justly weigh’d
What wrongs our arms may do, what wrongs we suffer,
And find our griefs heavier than our offenses.
We see which way the stream of time doth run,
And are enforc’d from our most quiet there
By the rough torrent of occasion,
And have the summary of all our griefs
(When time shall serve) to show in articles;
Which long ere this we offer’d to the King,
And might by no suit gain our audience.
When we are wrong’d and would unfold our griefs,
We are denied access unto his person
Even by those men that most have done us wrong.
The dangers of the days but newly gone,
Whose memory is written on the earth
With yet appearing blood, and the examples
Of every minute’s instance (present now)
Hath put us in these ill-beseeming arms,
Not to break peace, or any branch of it,
But to establish here a peace indeed,
Concurring both in name and quality.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: When ever yet was your appeal denied?
Wherein have you been galled by the King?
What peer hath been suborn’d to grate on you?
That you should seal this lawless bloody book
Of forg’d rebellion with a seal divine.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: My brother general, the commonwealth,
I make my quarrel in particular.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: There is no need of any such redress,
Or if there were, it not belongs to you.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: Why not to him in part, and to us all
That feel the bruises of the days before,
And suffer the condition of these times
To lay a heavy and unequal hand
Upon our honors?

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: O, my good Lord Mowbray,
Construe the times to their necessities,
And you shall say, indeed, it is the time,
And not the King, that doth you injuries.
Yet, for your part, it not appears to me,
Either from the King or in the present time,
That you should have an inch of any ground
To build a grief on. Were you not restor’d
To all the Duke of Norfolk’s signories,
Your noble and right well-rememb’red father’s?

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: What thing, in honor, had my father lost,
That need to be reviv’d and breath’d in me?
The King that lov’d him, as the state stood then,
Was force perforce compell’d to banish him;
And then that Henry Bullingbrook and he,
Being mounted and both roused in their seats,
Their neighing coursers daring of the spur,
Their armed staves in charge, their beavers down,
Their eyes of fire sparkling through sights of steel,
And the loud trumpet blowing them together;
Then, then, when there was nothing could have stay’d
My father from the breast of Bullingbrook,
O, when the King did throw his warder down
(His own life hung upon the staff he threw),
Then threw he down himself and all their lives
That by indictment and by dint of sword
Have since miscarried under Bullingbrook.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: You speak, Lord Mowbray, now you know not what.
The Earl of Herford was reputed then
In England the most valiant gentleman.
Who knows on whom fortune would then have smil’d?
But if your father had been victor there,
He ne’er had borne it out of Coventry;
For all the country in a general voice
Cried hate upon him; and all their prayers and love
Were set on Herford, whom they doted on
And bless’d and grac’d and did, more than the King—
But this is mere digression from my purpose.
Here come I from our princely general
To know your griefs, to tell you from his Grace
That he will give you audience, and wherein
It shall appear that your demands are just,
You shall enjoy them, every thing set off
That might so much as think you enemies.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: But he hath forc’d us to compel this offer,
And it proceeds from policy, not love.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: Mowbray, you overween to take it so;
This offer comes from mercy, not from fear.
For lo, within a ken our army lies:
Upon mine honor, all too confident
To give admittance to a thought of fear.
Our battle is more full of names than yours,
Our men more perfect in the use of arms,
Our armor all as strong, our cause the best;
Then reason will our hearts should be as good.
Say you not then our offer is compell’d.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: Well, by my will we shall admit no parley.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: That argues but the shame of your offense:
A rotten case abides no handling.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: Hath the Prince John a full commission,
In very ample virtue of his father,
To hear and absolutely to determine
Of what conditions we shall stand upon?

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: That is intended in the general’s name.
I muse you make so slight a question.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Then take, my Lord of Westmorland, this schedule,
For this contains our general grievances:
Each several article herein redress’d,
All members of our cause, both here and hence,
That are ensinewed to this action
Acquitted by a true substantial form
And present execution of our wills—
To us and to our purposes confin’d
We come within our aweful banks again,
And knit our powers to the arm of peace.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: This will I show the general. Please you, lords,
In sight of both our battles we may meet,
And either end in peace, which God so frame!
Or to the place of diff’rence call the swords
Which must decide it.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: My lord, we will do so.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: There is a thing within my bosom tells me
That no conditions of our peace can stand.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: Fear you not that; if we can make our peace
Upon such large terms and so absolute
As our conditions shall consist upon,
Our peace shall stand as firm as rocky mountains.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: Yea, but our valuation shall be such
That every slight and false-derived cause,
Yea, every idle, nice, and wanton reason,
Shall to the King taste of this action,
That were our royal faiths martyrs in love,
We shall be winnow’d with so rough a wind
That even our corn shall seem as light as chaff,
And good from bad find no partition.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: No, no, my lord, note this: the King is weary
Of dainty and such picking grievances,
For he hath found to end one doubt by death
Revives two greater in the heirs of life;
And therefore will he wipe his tables clean
And keep no tell-tale to his memory
That may repeat and history his loss
To new remembrance; for full well he knows
He cannot so precisely weed this land
As his misdoubts present occasion.
His foes are so enrooted with his friends
That, plucking to unfix an enemy,
He doth unfasten so and shake a friend,
So that this land, like an offensive wife
That hath enrag’d him on to offer strokes,
As he is striking, holds his infant up
And hangs resolv’d correction in the arm
That was uprear’d to execution.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: Besides, the King hath wasted all his rods
On late offenders, that he now doth lack
The very instruments of chastisement,
So that his power, like to a fangless lion,
May offer, but not hold.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: ’Tis very true,
And therefore be assur’d, my good Lord Marshal,
If we do now make our atonement well,
Our peace will, like a broken limb united,
Grow stronger for the breaking.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: Be it so.
Here is return’d my Lord of Westmorland.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: The Prince is here at hand. Pleaseth your lordship
To meet his Grace just distance ’tween our armies.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: Your Grace of York, in God’s name then set forward.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Before, and greet his Grace.—My lord, we come.

scene.stagedir: They march about the stage and then move forward to meet Prince John.

scene.scenelocation: Yorkshire. Another part of the Forest of Gaultree.
scene.scenepersonae: (Prince John of Lancaster, Mowbray, Hastings, Officer, Westmorland)
scene.scenedescription: Lancaster rebukes the Archbishop for taking up arms against the King, God’s representative on earth, but the prelate protests that he is warring not against the King but against the injustices of the time. Prince John agrees to present their protests to the King, claiming that some of his laws have been misunderstood and misapplied, and suggests that both sides dismiss their armies. The rebel army disbands first, and scatters, while the royalist forces stay in rank. Once he is certain that the rebel forces pose no more danger, Lancaster arrests all the rebel leaders, pointing out that he never promised them their safety, only that their complaints would be heard. The royal army chases after the rebels.
scene.stagedir: Enter Prince John of Lancaster and his army.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: You are well encount’red here, my cousin Mowbray,
Good day to you, gentle Lord Archbishop,
And so to you, Lord Hastings, and to all.
My Lord of York, it better show’d with you
When that your flock, assembled by the bell,
Encircled you to hear with reverence
Your exposition on the holy text
Than now to see you here an iron man, talking,
Cheering a rout of rebels with your drum,
Turning the word to sword and life to death.
That man that sits within a monarch’s heart
And ripens in the sunshine of his favor,
Would he abuse the countenance of the King,
Alack, what mischiefs might he set abroach
In shadow of such greatness? With you, Lord Bishop,
It is even so. Who hath not heard it spoken
How deep you were within the books of God?
To us the speaker in his parliament,
To us th’ imagin’d voice of God himself,
The very opener and intelligencer
Between the grace, the sanctities of heaven,
And our dull workings? O, who shall believe
But you misuse the reverence of your place,
Employ the countenance and grace of heav’n,
As a false favorite doth his prince’s name,
In deeds dishonorable? You have ta’en up,
Under the counterfeited zeal of God,
The subjects of his substitute, my father,
And both against the peace of heaven and him
Have here upswarm’d them.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Good my Lord of Lancaster,
I am not here against your father’s peace,
But as I told my Lord of Westmorland,
The time misord’red doth, in common sense,
Crowd us and crush us to this monstrous form
To hold our safety up. I sent your Grace
The parcels and particulars of our grief,
The which hath been with scorn shov’d from the court,
Whereon this Hydra son of war is born,
Whose dangerous eyes may well be charm’d asleep
With grant of our most just and right desires,
And true obedience, of this madness cured,
Stoop tamely to the foot of majesty.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: If not, we ready are to try our fortunes
To the last man.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: And though we here fall down,
We have supplies to second our attempt;
If they miscarry, theirs shall second them,
And so success of mischief shall be born,
And heir from heir shall hold his quarrel up
Whiles England shall have generation.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: You are too shallow, Hastings, much too shallow,
To sound the bottom of the after-times.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: Pleaseth your Grace to answer them directly
How far forth you do like their articles.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: I like them all, and do allow them well,
And swear here, by the honor of my blood,
My father’s purposes have been mistook,
And some about him have too lavishly
Wrested his meaning and authority.
My lord, these griefs shall be with speed redress’d,
Upon my soul they shall. If this may please you,
Discharge your powers unto their several counties,
As we will ours, and here between the armies
Let’s drink together friendly and embrace,
That all their eyes may bear those tokens home
Of our restored love and amity.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: I take your princely word for these redresses.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: I give it you, and will maintain my word,
And thereupon I drink unto your Grace.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: Go, captain, and deliver to the army
This news of peace. Let them have pay, and part.
I know it will well please them. Hie thee, captain.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: To you, my noble Lord of Westmorland.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: I pledge your Grace, and if you knew what pains
I have bestowed to breed this present peace,
You would drink freely. But my love to ye
Shall show itself more openly hereafter.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: I do not doubt you.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: I am glad of it.
Health to my lord, and gentle cousin, Mowbray.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: You wish me health in very happy season,
For I am on the sudden something ill.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Against ill chances men are ever merry,
But heaviness foreruns the good event.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: Therefore be merry, coz, since sudden sorrow
Serves to say thus, some good thing comes tomorrow.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Believe me, I am passing light in spirit.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: So much the worse, if your own rule be true.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: The word of peace is rend’red. Hark how they shout!

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: This had been cheerful after victory.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: A peace is of the nature of a conquest,
For then both parties nobly are subdued,
And neither party loser.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: Go, my lord,
And let our army be discharged too.
And, good my lord, so please you, let our trains
March by us, that we may peruse the men
We should have cop’d withal.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Go, good Lord Hastings,
And ere they be dismiss’d, let them march by.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: I trust, lords, we shall lie tonight together.
Now, cousin, wherefore stands our army still?

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: The leaders, having charge from you to stand,
Will not go off until they hear you speak.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: They know their duties.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: My lord, our army is dispers’d already:
Like youthful steers unyok’d, they take their courses
East, west, north, south, or, like a school broke up,
Each hurries toward his home and sporting-place.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: Good tidings, my Lord Hastings! For the which
I do arrest thee, traitor, of high treason,
And you, Lord Archbishop, and you, Lord Mowbray,
Of capital treason I attach you both.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: Is this proceeding just and honorable?

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: Is your assembly so?

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Will you thus break your faith?

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: I pawn’d thee none.
I promis’d you redress of these same grievances
Whereof you did complain, which, by mine honor,
I will perform with a most Christian care.
But for you rebels, look to taste the due
Meet for rebellion and such acts as yours.
Most shallowly did you these arms commence,
Fondly brought here and foolishly sent hence.
Strike up our drums, pursue the scatt’red stray;
God, and not we, hath safely fought today.
Some guard these traitors to the block of death,
Treason’s true bed and yielder-up of breath.

scene.scenelocation: Yorkshire. Another part of the Forest of Gaultree.
scene.scenepersonae: (Falstaff, Colevile, Prince John of Lancaster, Westmorland, Blunt, Bardolph)
scene.scenedescription: Falstaff captures the rebel Sir John Coleville, who surrenders peacefully. Falstaff gives him to Lancaster, who sends the prisoner off to be executed. Lancaster calls an end to the hunt against the rebels and leaves to visit his sick father, while Falstaff asks permission to pass through Glocuestershire (Shallow’s county) on his way back to London. Falstaff disdains the Prince for not drinking wine, since it makes him less of a man. He leaves to visit Shallow.
scene.stagedir: Alarum. Excursions. Enter Falstaff and Colevile, meeting.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What’s your name, sir? Of what condition are you, and of what place?

speech.speaker: COL.
speech.line: I am a knight, sir, and my name is Colevile of the Dale.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Well then, Colevile is your name, a knight is your degree, and your place the Dale. Colevile shall be still your name, a traitor your degree, and the dungeon your place, a place deep enough; so shall you be still Colevile of the Dale.

speech.speaker: COL.
speech.line: Are not you Sir John Falstaff?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: As good a man as he, sir, whoe’er I am. Do ye yield, sir? Or shall I sweat for you? If I do sweat, they are the drops of thy lovers, and they weep for thy death; therefore rouse up fear and trembling, and do observance to my mercy.

speech.speaker: COL.
speech.line: I think you are Sir John Falstaff, and in that thought yield me.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I have a whole school of tongues in this belly of mine, and not a tongue of them all speaks any other word but my name. And I had but a belly of any indifferency, I were simply the most active fellow in Europe. My womb, my womb, my womb undoes me. Here comes our general.

scene.stagedir: Enter Prince John of Lancaster, Westmorland, Blunt, and the rest.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: The heat is past, follow no further now;
Call in the powers, good cousin Westmorland.
Now, Falstaff, where have you been all this while?
When every thing is ended, then you come.
These tardy tricks of yours will, on my life,
One time or other break some gallows’ back.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I would be sorry, my lord, but it should be thus. I never knew yet but rebuke and check was the reward of valor. Do you think me a swallow, an arrow, or a bullet? Have I, in my poor and old motion, the expedition of thought? I have speeded hither with the very extremest inch of possibility; I have found’red ninescore and odd posts, and here, travel-tainted as I am, have, in my pure and immaculate valor, taken Sir John Colevile of the Dale, a most furious knight and valorous enemy. But what of that? He saw me, and yielded, that I may justly say, with the hook-nos’d fellow of Rome, “There, cousin, I came, saw, and overcame.”

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: It was more of his courtesy than your deserving.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I know not: here he is, and here I yield him, and I beseech your Grace let it be book’d with the rest of this day’s deeds, or by the Lord, I will have it in a particular ballad else, with mine own picture on the top on’t (Colevile kissing my foot), to the which course if I be enforc’d, if you do not all show like gilt twopences to me, and I in the clear sky of fame o’ershine you as much as the full moon doth the cinders of the element (which show like pins’ heads to her), believe not the word of the noble. Therefore let me have right, and let desert mount.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: Thine’s too heavy to mount.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Let it shine then.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: Thine’s too thick to shine.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Let it do something, my good lord, that may do me good, and call it what you will.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: Is thy name Colevile?

speech.speaker: COL.
speech.line: It is, my lord.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: A famous rebel art thou, Colevile.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: And a famous true subject took him.

speech.speaker: COL.
speech.line: I am, my lord, but as my betters are
That led me hither. Had they been rul’d by me,
You should have won them dearer than you have.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I know not how they sold themselves, but thou like a kind fellow gavest thyself away gratis, and I thank thee for thee.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: Now, have you left pursuit?

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: Retreat is made and execution stay’d.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: Send Colevile with his confederates
To York, to present execution.
Blunt, lead him hence, and see you guard him sure.
speech.stagedir: Exeunt Blunt and others with Colevile.
speech.line: And now dispatch we toward the court, my lords,
I hear the King my father is sore sick.
Our news shall go before us to his Majesty,
Which, cousin, you shall bear to comfort him,
And we with sober speed will follow you.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My lord, I beseech you give me leave to go through Gloucestershire, and when you come to court stand my good lord in your good report.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: Fare you well, Falstaff. I, in my condition,
Shall better speak of you than you deserve.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I would you had the wit, ’twere better than your dukedom. Good faith, this same young sober-blooded boy doth not love me, nor a man cannot make him laugh, but that’s no marvel, he drinks no wine. There’s never none of these demure boys come to any proof, for thin drink doth so over-cool their blood, and making many fish-meals, that they fall into a kind of male green-sickness, and then when they marry, they get wenches. They are generally fools and cowards, which some of us should be too, but for inflammation. A good sherris-sack hath a twofold operation in it. It ascends me into the brain, dries me there all the foolish and dull and crudy vapors which environ it, makes it apprehensive, quick, forgetive, full of nimble, fiery, and delectable shapes, which deliver’d o’er to the voice, the tongue, which is the birth, becomes excellent wit. The second property of your excellent sherris is the warming of the blood, which before (cold and settled) left the liver white and pale, which is the badge of pusillanimity and cowardice; but the sherris warms it, and makes it course from the inwards to the parts’ extremes. It illumineth the face, which as a beacon gives warning to all the rest of this little kingdom, man, to arm, and then the vital commoners and inland petty spirits muster me all to their captain, the heart, who great and puff’d up with this retinue, doth any deed of courage; and this valor comes of sherris. So that skill in the weapon is nothing without sack (for that sets it a-work) and learning a mere hoard of gold kept by a devil, till sack commences it and sets it in act and use. Hereof comes it that Prince Harry is valiant, for the cold blood he did naturally inherit of his father, he hath, like lean, sterile, and bare land, manur’d, husbanded, and till’d with excellent endeavor of drinking good and good store of fertile sherris, that he is become very hot and valiant. If I had a thousand sons, the first humane principle I would teach them should be, to forswear thin potations and to addict themselves to sack.
How now, Bardolph?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: The army is discharged all and gone.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Let them go. I’ll through Gloucestershire, and there will I visit Master Robert Shallow, esquire. I have him already temp’ring between my finger and my thumb, and shortly will I seal with him. Come away.

scene.scenepersonae: (King, Warwick, Thomas Duke of Clarence, Humphrey of Gloucester, Westmorland, Harcourt)
scene.scenedescription: The King is ready for his crusade, except that he is too weak to leave at present. Worried about Hal’s dissipation, he begs his son Thomas, Duke of Clarence, to exert his good influence on the oldest son, as the latter likes Clarence better than his other siblings. Henry bewails Hal’s attraction to unworthy companions, but Warwick insists the Prince is simply studying them. Westmoreland brings the news of the rebels’ defeat, and further news arrives of Northumberland and Lord Bardolph’s defeat by the sheriff of Yorkshire. Though overjoyed, the King suffers a fit of his illness. The King’s sons realize that he is dying.
scene.stagedir: Enter the King, carried in a chair, Warwick, Thomas Duke of Clarence, Humphrey of Gloucester, and others.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Now, lords, if God doth give successful end
To this debate that bleedeth at our doors,
We will our youth lead on to higher fields,
And draw no swords but what are sanctified.
Our navy is address’d, our power collected,
Our substitutes in absence well invested,
And every thing lies level to our wish.
Only, we want a little personal strength;
And pause us till these rebels, now afoot,
Come underneath the yoke of government.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Both which we doubt not but your Majesty
Shall soon enjoy.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Humphrey, my son of Gloucester,
Where is the Prince your brother?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I think he’s gone to hunt, my lord, at Windsor.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: And how accompanied?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I do not know, my lord.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Is not his brother Thomas of Clarence with him?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
